description.text: This is a little tool we use at the shop to defeat the interlocks on our SLA machines while we are doing all-too-frequent maintenance on the laser and mirrors. Yes, we use goggles - we're not that stupid! This model is actually my first attempt at CAD. I decided to try OpenSCAD rather than a more traditional tool because I'm much better at coding than I am at drawing! The part is based on measurements I took of an existing part. We only had one, and it seemed like it'd be a good idea to make a few more...
Important note: this part is measured in inches - convert if needed.

author: BeKnit

description.text:
this is a tool I designed for work where we will be putting headers on a few hundred feather boards. This jig helps hold the headers steady while soldering. My first design, seen in the photos, works, but not as intended. I redesigned it to use spring retention instead of just a drop in fit, and also expanded the relief for the LIPO connector. As of this time I have not reprinted and tested the redesign as i don't have my own printer to use. Hope you get some use out of this.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aIRUo3yduRM

Use switch_no_gap.stl if you have this anti wobbling design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067676

Use pusher_large.stl if you have this x-belt tensioner https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1999669 and adjust X movement line on the End GCode

I used a XL601 switch
https://es.aliexpress.com/store/product/10pcs-lot-A2-ship-switch-117S-21-15-2-pin-2-XL601-6A-KCD11-250V/1916362_32710014880.html

No SUPPORTS needed for the switch!!!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20+

Cura End GCode

+++++++++++++++++
;End GCode
M104 S0 ;extruder heater off
M140 S0 ;heated bed heater off (if you have it)
G91 ;relative positioning
G1 E-1 F300 ;retract the filament a bit before lifting the nozzle, to release some of the pressure
G1 Z+5.5 E-5 X-20 Y-20 F{travel_speed} ;move Z up a bit and retract filament even more
G90 ;Absolute Positioning
G1 X220 F3600 ; move 220mm to the right
G1 X-10 F3600 ; move 10mm to the left
M84 ;steppers off
G90 ;absolute positioning

+++++++++++++++++
///Change X220 value to reach switch
G1 X220 F3600 ; move 220mm to the right

title: MKS mini 16864 Mount for 2020 profile (v2)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 04.03.18 for Back MKS mini16864 2020 and 2040 mount (now v3):
My display finally arrived and I debugged the backside of the case. As Fed81 already pointed out, at least +5mm had to be added.

Update 26.02.18 for Front MKS mini16864 2020 and 2040 mount (now v2)
There was an unwanted collision bug between front and back cover. This is now corrected.

Update 25.02.18 for Back MKS mini16864 mount (now v2)
Fed81 commented, that the SD card slot of his MKS mini was colliding with the back side of the case. I added additional 1mm clearance to compensate for MKS mini fabrication tolerances.

This is a remix of lordwimseys' enclosure for the MKS mini 12684 LCD to mount it to vertical beams of 2020 profiles.

Two versions are available. One is for vertically mounting the other for mounting to the cutting side (face) of a 2040, 2060, 2080,... profile. The later is mainly usefull for CNC frames. The backside is identical for both mouting options.

For the vertical mounting on 2020 you will need:
4pcs M3x20 or 25 for case - holes are 3.2mm (oversized) as my printer is not calibrated for holesizes yet.
3pcs M3x10 for mounting - one hidden mounting point inside the back cover for increased stiffness.

For the 2040 mount you will need:
4pcs M3x20 or 25 for case - holes are 3.2mm (oversized) as my printer is not calibrated for holesizes yet.
2pcs M4x15 or more for mounting

Not tested as my display did not arrive yet.
But, I did a collision check with this CAD model https://grabcad.com/library/mks-mini-12864-v1-0-1

description.text:
Organize your cables and wires by using cable combs. This customizable thing can produce both open (clip on) and closed combs in all kinds of sizes. You may change a lot of features to fit your needs.

This thing uses a few levels of value verification to ensure the values you put in are feasible. Remember that printers can be crude and require more material to create a solid part. I recommend adding a bit of rigidity through the "Strength" value and increase the "Wire diameter" beyond your measured diameter due to the (often) small print moves which most likely fall off a bit short.

description.text:
This is a remix of Yakandu's Anycubic Kossel driver fan with breakouts for the TMC2130 CS ans SPI pins. This version adds a fourth breakout for those using TMC2130 for the extruder in addition to X, Y an Z axes.

Did not get a chance to print it myself yet (bit of a hen and egg problem... my TMC2130s tend to overheat during long prints despite already minimized current). Printed and it's working. The fit to the board is not as tight as I hoped for though.

I'm still having issues with the temperature of the extruder stepper, when doing relatively fast retractions in a fast sequence. Lowering the current is no option, because I'm starting to loose steps then. But it seems to work just fine with lower retraction speeds. I was probably overdoing things on that side ;-)

Take this as a word of warning: The TMC2130s are definitely worth their money (get the genuine SilentStepSticks version!), but are by no means an easy drop-in replacement. You need to invest some fine tuning to get them working perfectly.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

I printed mine with PLA, but ABS should work fine, too. Print using a brim if warping occurs.

title: LED Tower - Lights for Anycubic Delta Kossel Linear Plus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are mini LED towers for my Anycubic Linear Plus (Model late 2017/early 2018).
They fit onto the stepper mounts and can hold three 3mm LEDs each.

There are better lights on thingiverse, but I only had these simple LEDs in my parts bin... So if you're in the same boat: Enjoy.

The holes have a diameter of 4mm defined in the CAD, so you can push them further in (might need some glue!). For my printer they are a bit tight with 3mm LEDs, but I didn't set it up for better precision, yet.

I added a second variant with an additional hole in the bottom center to route the power cable. Those cables I had don't fit, but maybe someone else might find this variant handy.

Also added a cover for gluing to the back. This one should leave about 12mm of space for cable routing. Additionally the cover has a center space (5.5mm, which should leave about 0.5mm room) and 1.5mm poles to properly push in the LEDs.

I will not print the power-hole variant, since the only spare wires I had are to thick to route that way at all.

The tower height is intended for the heated bed holders I use, which are slightly higher than those coming as default (btw, I can really recommend these!):
https://www.thingiverse.com/make:441898
The heat bed is ~18.5mm above the 20x20 rails, the tower adds another 15mm on top of that.
I wanted to angle the LEDs at 80deg instead of 90deg, but I couldn't figure out how to do that in Autodesk. That's not too bad, since the tower can easily angled a little bit due to the rounded corners inside the bottom clip.

WARNING Be careful to fix your cables down somehow, or even better, isolate them with shrinking tube. YOU MIGHT GET SHORTS IF THEY WIGGLE TOO MUCH, and most printers vibrate a lot!
For obvious reasons they should also not block your timing belts ;)

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print standing, with 8mm brim but without support. Should take about 30 minutes per tower.

description.text:
My vision for this was to create a lock that would keep small children out but still let others have easy accsess

This is a first draft (now a 4th draft "Padlock 4" as of 2-18-2018)

Any makes and/or suggestions will be appreciated

Padlock 3:
The shackle in "Padlock 3" is 15mm taller than version 2 and the amount of supports needed has been reduced by a fair amount. (see print settings)

The slot in the bottom for turning the lock has been changed to a hex and two holes have been added to spread out the force needed to break it free. ( I will make a key for this if needed)

An extra hole has been added to the side to help remove supports (may not be needed but thought it would help)

Padlock 4:

more supports were removed to help break the lock free.

some side ports were not needed and were removed

this version has a bigger key hole

author: Elodin

description.text:
This is a small LED Cube in blue.

It was build with lots of blue 5mm LEDs. They are all soldered together with Ø0,6mm copper wire. All the cathodes of the flats are soldered together.
The soldering was done with a 3d-printable baseplate (it is in the package with the lasercut-files).

After that a circuit board was soldered. You can find the scheme for the circuit board as an image in this package. If you want to use another case or run another script, there is also a reset-button in the scheme, you don't have to use on your circuit board.

The LED Cube is standing in a Case that was lasercut out of Ø3mm thick wood. The parts were glued together. The side where the USB-Cable for Power supply is plugged in can be opened to show other people how the wires are connected inside. It really doesn't matter, which LED you connect to which output of the shift register, because it is a random display view. What you should connect right are the Pins for the transistors (otherwise it won't work correct)!

You can download the source and the compiled program on github
Replacment part for door laundry hook of Leifheit

comments.text:
If you bought one of the dial indicator gauges from Banggood, heads up. This won't work perfectly as printed. First of all, I printed it as shown on the Thingiverse STL preview. This is ok if you are willing to do some post processing for the hole. Otherwise, I think keeping the hole perpendicular to the bed will give best dimensional accuracy but the fan housing part might have some trouble. Second, the backside of this gauge (behind the graduations/numbers) is too large for this design. The gauge shaft doesn't sit flush against the printed part because of this. Also, the fit was too tight on my fan metal housing, but I just scraped off some material with a knife because I was too lazy to design my own.
Dial gauge in question: https://www.banggood.com/0_01mm-Accuracy-Measurement-Instrument-Dial-Indicator-Gauge-Tool-p-948936.html?rmmds=buy&cur_warehouse=CN

title: Sand Coaster -- Keep Your Soda Pop Can Clean and Free from Sand!

description.text:
Heading to the beach with your soda pop or other beverage in a can? Don't want to put it in the sand? After all, you could knock it over or get sand everywhere! Instead, use the Sand Coaster. It's a drink coaster you can use in the sand. Inspired by a product I found online but didn't want to pay $15 to purchase. Instead, I modelled it in Fusion 360 and printed it! Four legs dig into the sand to hold the coaster stable. Can also be used in a grassy yard. Enjoy!

(Yes, that is a poorly Photoshopped image. I printed one as a gift for my stepmother, but forgot to take a photo of it before giving it to her. She did report that she found "all kinds of uses for it" and loved it, though!)

remixed_from.author: pheneeny
remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

description.text:
Not strictly a remix as the part was designed from scratch but definitely used some dimensions from the respective original AM8 parts. Either way definitely worth linking to the referenced design.

Changes from the source design:

  • Extra material protruding from the underside to sink into the v slot channels.
  • Smaller holes in the endstop position so that the M2 screws stand a chance of biting into the material to stay in place.
  • Recess for the rod fixing screw's head to improve clearance for heated bed carriages that are running very low.
  • Rounded edges for a different appearance. Curved edges should be facing inward hence providing two variants of the non endstop version as I found it beneficial to have one of the pair at the front of the machine facing the other direction (again to improve space for a low riding heated bed carriage).

Measurements with calipers from original parts and modifications based on aesthetic and functional changes that I wanted to see in the design.

Some of the bevelled / curved edges were added later within Maya with careful edge selection!

title: Filament Passage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've built a housing for my printer out of 18mm thick wood. I wanted a passage for the filament so I've made this. You need to cut a 40mm square into the wood. Then put the top part on top (of course ... ;)) and attach it with 3mm screws.
You can then either put the "filament passage bottom counter sunk" in the hole from the other side and turn it by 90° towards the top part and fix it with 3mm screws too. The other possibility is using the "bottom flat" part and put M3 machine screws through both parts from the top.

description.text:
These are parts for an Avalon 741 Miner. The fan duct was created for noise reduction. These things have really loud fans. By adding about 4' of 4" dryer flex duct, the volume was seriously reduced. There are a couple of other duct designs out there in the Thingiverse. One was way too thick and heavy, and used 16m of filament. The other didn't fit any known duct size, either US or metric.

The mounting brackets have versions with screw holes that go on the bottom, and versions without screw holes for the top. I used ~1/2" wide Velcro strip that's used for securing cable bundles. The top T spacers are used to prevent pulling the two 741's together when the Velcro is tightened. The top L spacers are there to satisfy my OCD. The holes are sized for #6 sheet metal screws.

The 741 doesn't have enough lip on the front to create a piece that prevents front to rear movement. I solved this by putting a little rubber cement on the areas of the lower L's and T's that contact the bottom of the 741. This is enough to prevent it from skidding, but doesn't glue it irremovably into place.

author: fronzjr

description.text:
Simple yet effective auto leveling probe for Creality printers.
Probe Uses an endstop with the metal lever removed. You must have already removed the stock hotend/part cooling case as this mount the left hole. Works with OEM hotend and E3Dv6. Also fits CR-10 High Clearance fang. should fit others.

To probe simply push the probe all the way down and probe/home
before starting a print but after homing z axis push the probe up away from bed. You do not need to have your nozzle heated while probing, it will not effect anything.
I "auto-level" a few times a week with
G28;
G29;
M500;
In your start gcode place a M420 S1; After the G28 and it will use the stored auto-leveling data.

IMPORTANT: If you forget to lower the probe before homing Z the printer will run the nozzle into the bed until you turn it off.

Parts required
M3x20mm x1
M3x5mm x3 (old fan shroud screws + endstop screws)
M3 Nylock x1
Endstop x1 (I used my Z endstop)
Wire to extend Z endstop connector

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

comments.author: OriginalHotrodder

comments.text: You push the arm with the microswitch down. It is held by friction but also the endstop switch mechanism ends up directly under or behind the pivot so it doesn’t try to force the arm to swing back up when it probing. Simple and effective

description.text:
After the car wash place used silicone cleaner on the little insert that goes in the bottom of the cup holder, my can of Diet Mug Root Beer started sliding around in turns, and sloshing out of the can.

This adapter fixes the problem. The inside diameter is slightly larger than a soda can. It prevents the can from sliding around, yet the can is still easily inserted and removed. Although the can has sufficient clearance, there is a slight air resistance effect. I like this, but if you don't, you could add some "exhaust channels" on either the inside or outside faces.

Be sure to flip the object 180 degrees when added into the slicer program. You want the wider part on the print surface.

This will probably fit several different year models, but mine is a 2016.

You are looking at a print I like to call "Locker Buddy". It was used on my locker at work, and seeing it worked so well I decided to upload the files here for anyone that might get some use out of them. It was designed to fit inside the door of my locker, but can be placed anywhere that you can attach it to. I attached it to my locker using 2 Neodymium magnets (60 x 10 x 3 mm), they were rated for 12LB of holding strength, but seemed to be weaker than that. If you decide to use the exact magnets I did, I have included an indentation on the back of the container to where to place the magnets. I have also included a lip at the bottom of the container, which is equal to the thickness of the magnet, so the container will sit flush. If you use different magnets you will need to adjust the thickness of the lip to match the thickness of your magnet.

Thank you for taking the time in viewing my model.
Picture of them with the dividers inserted Showing the back of them, with the magnets glued on The dividers used in the containers Picture of the containers in use

description.text:
This is a basic component designed to slide along 20mm aluminium extrusion. I designed this for my FRC robotics team, The JaXon Falcon Works 6635, for our arm that will extend to place a hook on the rung for the final climb of the game. Our lift is designed to lift the hook up, not carry the weight of the robot, so the 3D printed parts will not cause any issues strength wise. The hook will be connected to two nylon straps connected to a winch, so the arm will let go of the hook once it is on the rung, then the winch will pull the robot up.

Uses M4 screws to connect to the extrusion and M3 to connect attachments to the sides.
Printed in Taulman Bridge Nylon.

Team

JPEC High School (Jackson Preparatory & Early College)
Jackson, Mi

description.text:
This is a primer panel designed for the Air Conception Nitro 200 paramotor. It holds the primer bulb and shut off valve and is designed to use the same components used by Aviator PPG who originally designed and sells the primer system.

Update 02/22/18: I had a request to design a panel that will fit above the frame crossbar, so I've add the design to this posting.

Designed to fit in the frame to the pilot's right and reachable when strapped in. The primer bulb is fitted with (2)M3x12 screws and nuts and the valve is press fit and glued into place. I've used Gorilla Glue with much success.

Just a simple shaving station to hold a razor, two bottles/tubes, and a cartridge of blades.
If you don't use DSC then I have some dimensions for the holders.

Razor cartridge - 92 mm x 50 mm x 15 mm (3 5/8 in x 2 in x 5/8 in)
Bottles/Tubes - anything under 50 mm (2 in) Diameter will fit

If your printer is good at bridging then you can skip the support material since it is only there to support the top of the drawer slot, it can get hard to remove, but just keep trying and you'll get it. (I found that a hammer and a sharp object help a lot.)

I hope you enjoy this design, this was just supposed to be a personal project but friends that I made some of these for said I should post it, so here I am!

If you want to email me for a slight deviation of the design or just need some help with your own projects email me at [email protected]
(Note: this email is one that I check regularly, however, it also gets crowded so I will go ahead and apologize here if I don't see your email. Thanks!)

PS: I know that the mm to inch conversions are not exact but this part is designed to have a lot of clearance for ease of use, so small deviations shouldn't matter.

I haven't printed this new version yet so if in the meantime anyone does let me know if there is any issues with it. A friend asked me to print a handle for his GoPro but the ones I saw in Thingiverse were not quite to my liking, so I made a new design.

comments.text:
I could put a small bevel at the base... but a couple minutes with a box cutter or sand paper gets rid of the sharp edge.
I could try the bevel but it still needs a brim at the bottom to keep the part from warping during printing, buy maybe that's just me because I print in PLA without a heatbed.
comments.author: MonZon

comments.text: You should trust yourself more :) PLA doesn't warp so much, and to prevent it you have to make sure your first layer is really really squished on the bed. Which means a good bed leveling, close to the noozle. In the end your print should be a little hard to remove from the bed because it sticked so good (good enough to prevent the warping). The only downside is that you may have to replace the tape more often :)

description.text:
I added M3 threads to mars_null's Adjustable CR-10 Z endstop, so now you can use the original screws that mount the end stop switch to the adapter without having to tap the holes.

I also increased the height of the slide rail so that you can actually lower the Z end stop by about 3mm from stock. Before the remix, you could only raise the end stop.

Lowering the end stop allows you to move the extruder closer to the bed, compressing the springs a bit and stabilizing the bed a bit more.

I limited lowering the end stop to 3mm because if you lower it much more, the wheel/roller will hit the bracket before the gantry hits the end stop.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

print_settings.Notes:: Print the base and the lid separately. Print the lid upside down. Lower resolution yields a much nicer print. Once printed, several steps are outlined in the Post-Printing section.

title: Lithophane Lamp Frame -- Optimized for Minimal Frame Thickness
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A lithophane uses backlighting to shine through a sheet of plastic where thicker portions of the plastic appear darker and thinner portions of the plastic appear lighter. The resulting effect is a glowing, black-and-white (grayscale) photo that "pops-out" of the plastic. It's really beautiful!

This lithophane lamp arranges 5 images in a cube that sits on a table and illuminates all sides simultaneously. It was inspired by the good work of Mafo [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1370792], I just had different design goals (as explained in the "How I Designed This" section, below).

A few notes:

  • This lamp accepts five 100 mm × 100 mm × 3 mm lithophanes. It is optimized for lithophanes that have a 3 mm bezel around the edge.
  • This lamp has a post in the center upon which you can spiral an LED strip for illumination. For best results in illuminating the top panel, a little bit of soldering is required.
  • Since this lamp is designed for LED strip lights, heat production is not a significant concern.

Needed supplies:

  • LED strip lights (I purchased mine for about USD$4 from ebay, though this was with 30-day shipping from China).
  • Power supply for LED strip lights (not all LED strips come with one; I had plenty of suitable ones lying around).
  • A few small scraps of thin-gauge wire (I think I used 20 awg).
  • Soldering iron and related supplies.
  • Five 100 mm × 100 mm × 3 mm lithophanes (instructions on how to produce these are provided in the Post-Printing section).
  • One small zip tie for strain relief of the power cable.

Please click/tap Like/I Made One to help other people find this model.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print the base and the lid separately. Print the lid upside down. Lower resolution yields a much nicer print. Once printed, several steps are outlined in the Post-Printing section.

Selecting and Preparing the Photos

Lithophanes work well with photos that work well as grayscale. Since not all photos work well as grayscale, not all photos work well as lithophanes. Usually, those that have fairly high color contrasts and a distinct subject work best. Furthermore, fine details are lost in a lithophane, so it is best to avoid photos that rely on those, such as small lettering, a busy pattern on the subject's shirt, etc. It also can help to use photo editing software to isolate the subject from the background a bit (I did this in the photos used in the example). Finally, the photos should be cropped to a square aspect ratio.

A few sources of Lithophane inspiration and additional documentation that helped me tremendously:

  • http://www.instructables.com/id/Litophanes-How-to-3D-Print-your-photos/
  • http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-3D-Print-a-Photo-Lithophanes-101/
Converting the Photos to STL Files

There are several ways to do this. Cura does this natively, though it provides very few fine controls. I've also read that you can purchase software to handle this step I found great success using the http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ website (free). A few specific settings to note (instructions accurate as of January 2018):

  1. Click Images > Choose Files to upload your photo (you'll do this separately for each photo).
  2. Click Settings > Model Settings.
  3. Set the Maximum Size to 100.
  4. Set the Thickness to 3.
  5. Set the Border to 3.
  6. Set the Thinnest Layer 1.6 (this was four times the nozzle thickness on my Anet A8, which is what I found through experimentation was thick enough that no holes or gaps would be formed).
  7. Set the Vectors Per Pixel to 5 (4 may suffice for your needs).
  8. Click Settings > Image Settings.
  9. Click Negative Image.
  10. Click Model.
  11. Click Refresh (the button below the preview area, not the browser refresh button).
  12. Click Download.
  13. Save your .stl file.
3D Printing the Lithophane .STL Files

While it may seem most natural to print the photo lithophanes flat against the print bed, you run the risk of warping ruining the print. You would also be limited to your nozzle width for the image resolution. Instead, it's better to build the lithophane perpendicular to the print bed--freestanding in the air. More specifically, if your print bed moves (as opposed to only the print head moving in both X and Y), then it is better to align your print along the axis of bed motion. This helps the lithophane resist any wobbling as the print bed jerks. So, for my Anet A8 where the print bed moves along the Y-axis, I've rotated the lithophane to be largely in the YZ plane, so the "face" of the lithophane points to the left or the right of the printer.

Wiring the LED Strip

Begin with the end of the LED strip at the bottom of the post in the middle of the lamp, nearly parallel to the floor, but angled slightly up. The angle will be just enough such that once the LED strip makes one complete loop around the center post, it will rest just above where the LED strip began. Continue in a spiral loop up the center post until the top. For best results, cut small strips of LED (cutting according to where the manufacturer recommends) to cover the top, paying attention to which side is positive and which side is negative so as to minimize crossing-over of wires in the next step. Then, solder some scrap wire to connect the initial LED strip to the first strip on the top of the post. Continue until all strips are connected.

At the bottom of the frame, there are four legs which connect the corners to the center post. Under one of those legs is a small gap. Lay a zip tie under that leg, in the gap.

Assembling the Lithophanes

Four lithos slide into the sides from the top. The fifth litho should friction-fit into lid from the underside. If it doesn't stay very well, it will be supported by small supports in the corners of the base.

My design goals for this model were:

  • To accommodate LED strip lighting as the lighting source.
  • Ensure the thickness of the frame was as small as possible while remaining equal on all sides and providing sufficient strength.
  • To make the model parameterizable so that users can enter custom lithophane sizes and the frame will adjust, accordingly (I started down this path but haven't fully succeeded in this one).

title: Tronxy X5S Stabilized Carriage for Hotend

description.text:
Background

I am putting my x5s together and after installing the mega gantry brackets, I noticed my hotend carriage seemed like an extremely week point. It would wobble around with very little pressure.

I believe most of this comes from how the spacers isolate the wheels far from the carriage, producing very little clamping force between the top and bottom wheels. By eliminating the need for the spacers, we can reduce the moment generated by the forces applied to the carriage through inconsistencies in belts/alignment etc, by reducing the distance.

v1

I have printed and fitted v1, which seems to be significantly better than the stock carriage. There are just holes for the fasteners (no captive nuts or anything), but I think this would work if you want to try this one out before I iterate on the second version a couple times.

v2

Update: I printed and install v2, which seems to be significantly more stiff than v1. Trying to flex it at all by hand is really difficult. This is definitely usable, and will free me up to go ahead and finish building the printer up. I'll probably follow up with a v3, but might be a few days.

Video of installed v2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gCRDgNma6bA

Improvements over v1

  • This fixes one mistake on the wiring mount.
  • Added another part to the wiring mount to better capture it so it can't fall down as much
  • It increases the material around the wheels, while also decreasing the gap between the 2020 and the channel it rides in within this carriage by 1mm. (not sure how much this will help over v1, might be marginal)
  • It adds a rail for the 2020 to ride on, with the only purpose to add more material where the carriage is the thinnest

Discovered Issues with v2:

  • Captive nut holes were too small for me, and too difficult to install. I could, but required some effort.
  • The slots for the belts were a hair too tight in v2. I could get them through, but took a little effort.
  • All of the small fastener holes were too small, need to make sure these will work with m3 screws. I had to drill them out by hand.

v3

ToDo

Other Options

  • I'm also considering combining the original carriage with a printed spacer to get the best of both worlds
  • Another option would be to add another wheel on the bottom to limit the twisting

Printer:

XYZPrinting Davinci 1.0a

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Adaptive Slicing (Slic3r) ~65% Quality

Infill:

40% Honeycomb

Notes:

I used ABS, since it is easy for me to print with by davinci printer and would avoid any heat issues PLA might have. I'm sure PETG would be a reasonable choice as well.

Supplies
  • Uses the stock wheels and hardware, minus the spacers
  • Carriage to Extruder Mount: 2x m3 nuts and 2x 10 or 12mm m3 screws
  • Wiring Mount: 2x m3 nuts and 2x 10mm m3 screws

comments.text: I received my printer two weeks ago and I have been modding it with some mods on Thingiverse and my remixes to their mods but one of the authors (sgabolab) has a no derivative in their license so I can't put up my remix for anyone. In my mod it brought things together and made it so my carts could use eccentric nuts and let me tell you that was a night and day difference. I just finished drilling the third hole bigger on my Extruder plate (use 9/32 or 5/16 as I was chamfering the hole with 5/16 and it caught and drilled the hole to that size but works just as well) so my Extruder carriage now sports an eccentric and I can tilt the bar and down it comes so no real friction unlike the original which was dang hard to move (the L/R carts with the eccentrics are the same way just smooth and a light touch to slide).

description.text:
Tired of all the same old grips that aren't comfortable for extended play times, well this is the grip for you. I borrow the design from a similar one for the Switch and tweaked it some so that it would fit on my N3dsXL. I removed some of the material so that you would be able to eject the games, and be able to press the power button.

Print this standing up
I printed mine at 20% infill, 4 outer shell layers, and 0.3mm layer height on my mk2s, print took roughly 6 to 7 hours to complete, then I finished it off with a few coats of plastidip for grip.

If you have a clear case on your 3ds you can increase the print size by roughly 2 to 3% to get the case to fit in as well.

*UPDATE 2/10/18 - added an STL file for the older model 3DS XL

title: E3D-v6 and Volcano Cooler - Fan Duct Mount

description.text:
50mm blower print cooler that mounts to the standard 30mm fan duct of the e3d-v6 and clones, making this cooler compatible with (space permitting) any printer with that hotend. Takes away the need for the hotend mount or gantry to support mounting a fan.

Inspired by watching too many videos of in-development printers testing without a print fan, especially the hangprinter.

The printer in the picture is a new design, stay tuned for when it's posted!

EDIT 2/3:

  • Fixed a small problem with the model that came up when I changed a param.
  • Guides changed to no longer need supports.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:
  • Brackets with guides have nubs that help keep the fan straight if the screw ever gets too loose.
  • Heater cartridge wires may get in the way of a second fan. This isn’t a problem with the Volcano.

Materials (per-side):

1x
  • 5015 (50mm) blower fan
  • M5 hexnut or nylock nut
  • M5x20mm screw
  • M3 hexnut
  • M3x6mm+ screw (longer works, shorter is better)

Assembly:

  1. Unscrew 30mm coldend fan. Reuse screws to attach the bracket, they should still reach into the fan duct.
  2. Embed M5 nut in bracket. Screw on fan and make sure the output is horizontal before tightening.
  3. Embed M3 nut in the notch at the back of the nozzle. Slide onto the output of the fan, and use the M3 screw to clamp the nozzle in place through the embedded nut.

title: Clothespin Mini Clamps/ Modular Clamping System

description.text:
This turns a clothespin into a useful clamp for holding small parts, soldering, etc. The clamp includes a channel for adding elastic bands to increase pressure.

Also included is a holder that will hold four of these pin clamps in a vertical orientation. The clamps should click into place and release with a protruding button. This holder will fit along the edge of the weighted base of my modular clamping system.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2759738

The holder requires 4 x No. 0 (4 x 1/2) wood screws to assemble as well as thin CA glue.

To assemble:

  • Align the holes on the clip piece with the clamp back using the slightly protruding disks on the clamp back. Attach the two pieces by flooding the edges of the holes and the sides where the pieces join with CA glue. Don't glue along the upper edge or you might block the flexible clips.
  • Screw 4 x No. 0 screws into the sockets in the base. Gradually tighten these into their sockets until the assembly clicks securely into the sockets of the weighted base like a Lego brick. If you over tighten the screw so that the socket won't easily enter the hole, file or sand back the lower rim of the socket.
  • Place the clothespin in the frame and secure by flooding the seams of the bottom half with CA glue. Put the jaws on the end and secure with CA glue.
  • You might want to line the jaws with something soft and grippy. I find that the rubber from an inflatable balloon works well. Glue this down with thin CA glue and trim with a sharp knife. The rubber from an elastic band seems too thick and flexible.

Keep in mind that the species of clothespin that I find at my local dollar store may not available in your corner of the universe. Check the image with the included dimensions before making this thing.

Prusa

i3 MK2S

description.text:
Originally produced by Games Workshop for their 6mm scale table top wargame, Epic. They have since abandoned all support for their game, so I modeled this in Autodesk Inventor for any avid wargamers.

Modelled at true-scale 1:300 so it is larger than the official GW models; It may match the FW models since they care about scale!

Epic is being re-released as Adeptus Titanicus some time in the near future, though reports indicate it will initially be titans only. Apparently it will be 8mm scale instead of 6mm, so I suggest that anyone wanting to print this for AT gaming should upscale it by 133%.

print_settings.Notes:: You can add a brim if you suffer from warping or adhesion problems. The infill should be at least 20% to get enough strength. All provided stl files are intended for a layer height of 0.2mm, but you can create your own files by customizing the scad file.

title: Improved Customizable Bag Clip - More stable - PLA compatible
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The reason I created this thing is I really liked the idea of printing these bag clips, but I was just not happy with the original design because of several reasons. The most important one is just that there are multiple different types of bags and the original design was just not flexible enough to be suitable for all of them.

Because of this I first created a customizable remake of the original clips with the possibility to set the legth height and width as well as other parameters like the amount of noses and slots to hold the bag and the opening angle since the infill should not be parallel to the perimeters in order to get a stable result.

Afte printing several clips in both PLA and ABS in differnt sizes like you can see on the picture with blue ones being PLA and black ones ABS I realized that especially for the big ones the axle is just too brittle. You can also see that at some of the clips the axle broke of. Furthermore to improve adhesion with ABS I added a brim which was hard to remove at the axle after the print.

Because of all this I changed the axle design to be much more stable and easier printable. The main thing changed is the axle now being part of the other arm and the second arm having a ring around the axle. At the same time this allows maximum opening angle to be increased beyond 180°. I have already printed some clips with the new design and the work extremly well, which is why I want to share this design with you.

I'm providing both the original remake and the improved design, but I would always reccommend the improved design. The parameters from the scad file are the following:

  • Clip_Length: The length of the clip that is actually useable. The complete clip is longer because of the area needed for the axle.
  • Clip_Height: Simply the height of the clip.
  • Arm_Thickness: The actual thickness of one of the two arms.
  • Extrusion_Width: The extrusion with of your printer. (Usally your nozzle diameter)
  • Layer_Height: Your desired layer height.
  • Amount_Noses: The amount of noses and slots to create for holding the bag.
  • Noses_Size: The width how far a nose is standing out from the arm and how deep a slot is.
  • Opening_Angle: The ablge how far the clip is opened. (I recommend 90° for the improved and 30° or 60° for the original design)
  • Clip_Overstand: The length how far the actual clipping part has to be bowed to snap. (I reccomend 2mm for PLA and 3mm for ABS, because its more flexible)

All the stl files provided are for a 0.4mm nozzle with a 0.2mm layer height and can be printed in PLA.

Update 1:

Since some Browser based SCAD tools use a deprecated version of OpenSCAD which causes problems with the rendering, I uploaded the file "Customizeable_Bag_Clip_Improved_Deprecated.scad" which you can try to use if the clipping nose is not being created.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or customize

Infill:

20% or more

Notes:

You can add a brim if you suffer from warping or adhesion problems. The infill should be at least 20% to get enough strength. All provided stl files are intended for a layer height of 0.2mm, but you can create your own files by customizing the scad file.

If you added a brim, use a sharp knife to remove it from the area near the axle where the two arms are connected by it. If you used the original design, you also have to free the axle from the brim. This is not necessary with the improved design. Also remove the brim from the slit at the actual clipping part.
The first time moving the clip requires some strength, but afterwards it should move pretty easily.

title: Flex Door Stopper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple door stopper design to prevent damage a wall or door. It was printed with flexible filament so that it returns back to its original shape when it has been deformed. The stoppers has diameters of 40, 35 and 30 mm, and thicknesses of 10 and 5 mm.
The printing was very frustrating at first because the filament was always swelled out on the extruder. You can use a special extruder or use a special adapter for your extruder.

Links:

  • Flexible filament: http://amzn.to/2BVe2Ke
  • Flex extruder: http://amzn.to/2E2wouP
  • 3D Printer: http://amzn.to/2EK2Lj6
  • Special adapter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829810

Einfacher Türstopper, um Schäden an einer Wand oder einer Tür zu vermeiden. Ich habe es mit flexiblem Filament gedruckt, so dass es die Stöße gut abfängt und immer wieder in seine Ausgangsform zurückkehrt. Die Türstopper haben Durchmesser von 40, 35 und 30 mm und sind 10 und 5 mm dick.
Anfangs war das Drucken sehr frustrierend, da das Filament immer wieder am Extruder rausgequollen ist. Wenn ihr auch Probleme habt, dann nutzt entweder einen speziellen Extruder für flexibles Filament oder druckt vorher einen Adapter für den Extruder in PLA oder ABS, so dass das Filament nicht mehr raus quillt.

Links:

  • Flexibles Filament: http://amzn.to/2DZbaC1
  • Flex Extruder: http://amzn.to/2DYnuCz
  • 3D Drucker: http://amzn.to/2ECWZzN
  • Spezial Adapter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829810

Here you can see in quick motion how I print the door stopper.
Hier mal ein Video als Zeitfraffer, wie ich den Türstopper drucke.

https://youtu.be/_YEdPW4f2S0

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12

Infill:

25%

Notes:

It is very difficult to print flexible filament. Depending on your filament you have to make different settings. I have used flexible Filament, with 205 degrees Celsius as extruder temperature and 60 degrees Celsius as bed temperature.

Generally:

  • Prints very slowly
  • Disable retraction

Optionally:
You can use a special extruder or use a filament change adapter for your extruder.

Links:

  • Flexible filament: http://amzn.to/2BVe2Ke
  • Flex extruder: http://amzn.to/2E2wouP
  • Anet A8: http://amzn.to/2EK2Lj6
  • Special adapter: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829810

Es ist sehr schwierig, flexibles Filament zu drucken. Abhängig vom Filament, müssen verschiedene Einstellungen vorgenommen werden. Ich habe flexibles Filament verwendet, mit 205 Grad Celsius als Extrudertemperatur und 60 Grad Celsius als Betttemperatur.

Allgemein:

  • Druckt sehr langsam
  • Deaktiviert das Zurückziehen (Retract)

Optional:
Wenn ihr auch Probleme habt, dann nutzt entweder einen speziellen Extruder für flexibles Filament oder druckt vorher einen Adapter für den Extruder in PLA oder ABS, so dass das Filament nicht mehr raus quillt.

Links:

  • Flexibles Filament: http://amzn.to/2DZbaC1
  • Flex Extruder: http://amzn.to/2DYnuCz
  • Anet A8: http://amzn.to/2ECWZzN

remixed_from.title: ANET A8 Z Endstop fine adjustment

description.text:
Version 1.1 and 2.1 are a little bit smaller for use of diffrent screws. Normally it is an M3 screw but it also works with an Spax but not as good as with an fine screw.

Original Description from the Anet A8 remix from ibschreiber.

" The Leg has a 2.95 mm hole for 3mm screws which gives more stability, no more drilling or heating needed anymore.
The Foot is completely redesigned also for 3mm screw and has a big flat bottom and is easy to screw on to the screw and is used for calibration as a turning knob ;-)

Assembly instructions:

Mount the switch holder to the frame, add the switch
put a M3x35 or similar through the legs hole
add the foot to the screw, tighten it a little bit, not too much or you'll deform the bottom surface. You can glue the screw into the foot to give it a better hold.

Calibration:
just turn the screw using the six sided foot, enjoy!

Note:
A good calibrated printer is essential for the screws to fit the holes tightly!

If it doesn't fit, just scale the model up 1-3% ;-)
To set up your z axis, just remember: one complete turn of the M3 screw is 0.5 mm"

title: Dual rope pulley for Snapshackle swivel end pin for Wave harness

description.text:
Using an old wave harness bar I cut off the hook, ground the stubs flat and ran a 6mm tough cord looped between the inside strap loop edges. then I bought a stainless steel swivel snapshackle (small size) from ANZOR and fixed the swivel shackle end around the cord. After a few long sessions though, I could see the cord flattening where it was running against the pin. And so the snapshackle pulley was born...
End result is a wave harness making toe-side riding MUCH easier.

Printer:

DIY Rostock with many WC head holder.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

0.6

Notes:

I used 4 bottom layers, 4 walls and 60% fill.

Openscad

A cylinder (filled rod) created for the outside dimensions of the pulley.
Next subtract a slightly fatter rod from the centre to make the hole for the plain shackle rod.
To make a grippy surface for the cords to run around I subtracted 2 x rings of spheres.
Then I tidied up the right angle cylinder ends by intersecting the result with a slightly flattened sphere to trim around the sharp ends..

remixed_from.author: mrm64
remixed_from.title: Dried PVAc Bed V2 for PLA Printing

title: Dried PVAc Bed V2.1 for PLA Printing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a print bed suitable for PLA printing.

Changes from V2

  • Became printable without raft
    However, if you print large models you need a helperdisks.
  • Does not decrease printable space

Requirements

  • Wet sandpaper (150 grit) or sander
    Used to make the PVAc layer thin and flat.
  • PVAc glue
  • Wet sandpaper (400 grit)
  • Thin double-sided tape
    For heavy use of heated beds, those with heat resistance are desirable.
  • Plane printbed

Steps

  1. Put thin double-sided tape on printbed
  2. Peel off peeling layer from double-sided tape
  3. Put wet sandpaper (400 grit) on double-sided tape
  4. Paint PVAc glue on wet sandpaper (400 grit)
  5. Spread PVAc glue and make it flat
  6. Wait for PVAc glue to dry
  7. Paint PVAc glue on dented part of dried PVAc layer
  8. Wait for PVAc glue to dry
  9. Sanding PVAc layer thin and flat with wet sandpaper (150 grit) or sander

title: Compact Bowden Extruder Plus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This extruder is the 4th generation counted from the original Compact Bowden Extruder.

Basic Data

  • Extruder type: bowden
  • Drive method: direct drive
  • Stepper motor: NEMA 17
  • Filament diameter: 1.75mm
  • Drive gear: MK8 drive gear
  • Push-fit connecter: PC4-M6

Requirements

  • Body/Idler
    • 1 x NEMA 17 Stepper motor
    • 1 x Heatsink for Nema 17 stepper motor (optional)
      • If you printed the body with PLA filament, it would be better to attach a heatsink
    • 1 x MK8 drive gear
      • Outer diameter: 9mm
      • Length: 11mm
      • Hob diameter: 7mm
      • Bore: 5mm
    • 1‒2 x PC4-M6 push-fit connecter
    • 1 x Threadlocker
      • Lock the thread on the push-fit connecter
    • 1 x Soft pick
      • Used to clean the drive gear automatically
    • 1 x 625ZZ bearing (or 625-2RS bearing)
    • 1 x 608ZZ bearing (or 608-2RS bearing)
    • 2 x M3x8mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x10mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x15mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x40mm screws
      • Using the flat head screws makes it easier to insert and remove the spring compressor and makes it easier to evenly tighten the left and right screws
      • When using full thread screw, stick an adhesive tape on a place to touch the idler and the washer board, the idler movement is becomes smooth
    • 2 x Compression springs
      • Wire diameter: 0.6‒0.8mm
      • Outer diameter: 5‒8mm
      • Free length: 12‒15mm
    • 4 x M3 hex nuts
  • Mount (Type A)
    • 2 x M3 screws
    • 2 x M3 hex nuts
    • 2 x M3 washers
  • Mount (Type B)
    • 2 x M3 screws
    • 2 x M3 t-slot nuts (or hex nuts)
    • 2 x M3 washers

Print Settings

  • Body
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Perimeter count: 4
    • Infill: 30%
  • Idler
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Perimeter count: 4
    • Infill: 90%
  • Bearing spacer
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
  • Motor spacer
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
  • Spring compressor
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
  • Washer board
    • Resolution: 0.2mm

Spring Compressor

The spring compressor has a function to quick release/restore the spring pressure.
Please attach it to the screw head when using the 3D printer, and remove it from the screw head when finished using the 3D printer.
The burden on idlers when 3D printers are not used decreases, and the idlers becomes hard to break.

title: Modular Sorting System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: Added two more inlays. One with an edge length of 6u 2u 1u and one with 8u 2u 1u

Being a maker means having a lot of small pieces lying around. Mostly, you have hundreds and hundreds of bolts, nuts, washer or similar hardware at hand. Keeping these little parts organized is troublesome. Sure, there are a lot of organizers and sorting boxes out in the wild. However, having one that is modular, extensible and adaptable to your changing needs is not easy to find.

So why not print one out yourself? A 3D-printer makes it so easy to get the right things for the right use case without having to travel the world to find it. Isn't that the best thing having a 3D-printer?

I designed this modular sorting system over one year ago but hadn't had the time to polish the design since then. Nevertheless, I am using it for the same amount of time on a daily basis and thought: why not share it with you?

So here it is. While still being a "work in progress" it is, nevertheless, a fully functional first set.

The inlays are exchangeable and can be arranged at 90° angles. Furthermore, they have fillets between the bottom and side walls which makes taking even small parts out of them very easy. Because the fillets require some storage space, I have inserted it only on specific sides, depending on the size of the inlay. However, because you can arrange the inlays at wish, you can turn the fillet-side the way that is most convenient for you.

Speaking of the size of the inlays: this system has a unit size of 2cm, which is labeled 1u.
Therefore, every inlay edge will be an even factor of this unit thus the number in front of the "u" is this factor.

Note: This project is for inlays of 1u in height, only. I plan to release other height measures in separate projects because also new enclosure boxes are needed then. Otherwise, this project would become too cluttered.

Currently, the following inlays are available:

  • 2u 2u 1u (4 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm)
  • 4u 2u 1u (8 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm)
  • 4u 4u 1u (8 cm x 8 cm x 2 cm)
  • 6u 2u 1u (12 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm)
  • 8u 2u 1u (16 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm)

Furthermore, a first storage box for the inlays is available which can hold four times three times one inlays.

Your opinion on this design and suggestions to make it even better is appreciated

Please also take a look at my other designs, printer parts, and tools.

If you like to support me and my work, please consider to follow me

  • here at Thingiverse
  • Twitter
  • Instagram
  • YouTube

Sending a tip over Thingiverse will buy me some coffee to stay productive. :-)


Thank you very much.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

at wish...

Notes:

The Inlays are reasonably easy to print. For sturdiness use more perimeters (e.g., 3) and a denser infill. I used 20% infill in this case.

The enclosure box can also be printed with settings at wish. To achieve the same results as in the example pictures here, I printed the enclosure box with no bottom and top layers. The infill was honeycomb at 20% density.

The hinges are designed with 45° inclination. Therefore, no supports are needed in most cases.

Enclosure Box assembly

The hinges have to be just clicked into each other. If you experience some friction, clean your hinge's edges with a knife. That's it.

title: G-Quad 150
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this quad to be relatively durable and easy to print. It can be used with either 8mm carbon rods or printed rods for attaching the motor pods to frame. (Once aligned just add a drop of super glue) Using rods makes the quad adjustable to some extent. Just cut or print longer rods and you can increase the span to your needs. I have included two sized of printed rods 35mm and 37.5mm which provide spans of 145mm and 150mm respectfully. For motors I recommend a 1306 with 3" props.

With the 3D printed arms and no lid the frame weighs in at 27g. The lid will add an additional 6g for a total of 33g. I assume most people will probably fly without the lid. If you want to save a few more grams I would say using carbon rods will help.

I printed mine with PLA which is a pretty dense plastic. It is also brittle compared to say PETG or ABS. This quad is really designed for recreational flying. If you plan to "race" the quad I suggest using either of these over PLA.

author: AnotherDIYGuy

description.text:
This is a printable fine mesh screen, optimized for slicing with skeinforge.
When trying to print a fine mesh pattern (2-3mm mesh size), I ran into issues. Skeinforge sliced the mesh into tiny squares - as it should i guess. Problem is, this takes ages to print, and the resulting object is far from ideal. Not as nice looking as it could have been and not that strong either. 
This mesh screen solves this by layering the perpendicular threads on top of each other. A tiny tiny gap between them ensures that skeinforge will detect them as 'lines' rather than 'squares. During the slicing process, this tiny gap is discarded and the result is a nice looking mesh pattern. 
This design worked really well for me printing 1.2 mm mesh screens with 'lines' 2 mm apart and 0.45 mm wide.
Im printing with a layer height of 0.3 mm and w over h ratio of 1.5.

Design is fully parametrized.
Download the openscad file and adjust the parameters. Example for a square mesh screen and round mesh screen inside the scad file. Code is organized in modules, so this object can be used as a library.

description.text:
The attachments allow to put the printer in an enclosure and feed the filament from outside the enclosure to the printer.

The used pneumatic fittings (e.g. https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-lot-3d-peinter-parts-Pneumatic-Fittings-PC4-M6-Bore-4-5mm-For-4mm-PTFE-Tube/32844578819.html ) still allow to quickly release the PTFE bowden cables to resolve filament jams etc.

I customized it to fit the M6 threads of these fittings. I printed them using PLA and they do not require glueing to the extruder. Screwing in the fittings requires a wrench, this fit is very tight.

title: RCBS Rockchucker Primer Catcher
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After trying a couple of designs here, I made my own so I had room for my auto-eject system.

As my auto-eject wasn't designed at that point, I made a left-hand and right-hand version of this incase I didn't have room.

Designed for the rockchucker IV, but might fit previous incarnations? It only sits on the main upright, so you may be lucky.

It is held in place with 6.3mm diameter (1/4") Neodymium Magnets that are pocketed in the rear of the catcher. The holes are slightly undersize, allowing for a snug fit, or requiring a little reaming (which is what I wanted to do) to ensure a perfect fit. I then super-glued the magnets in place.

IF you're not prepared to wait for magnets in the post, I suppose you could find a way of holding it in place with rubber bands or cable ties. :D

EDIT: Lastly, If you make one and it doesn't work for you, please let me know - I might be able to tweak it for you if you don't have the ability. similarly, if you make one and like it - post pictures :D

update
2018/2/19
The depth of counter bore of whirl-stop was too deep, and M3 20mm bolt stick out of the back side.

2018/2/22
I've modified whirl-stop part again.

The amount of change of the sensor height is 1 mm per one rotation of the dial.

When viewed from the top, turning it clockwise will narrow the gap between the nozzle and the bed, turning counterclockwise will widen the gap between the nozzle and the bed.

description.text:
This is the Flow Vase, because I made it in a Flow :-)

the idea is to print it in “vase mode” or “spiral outer contour mode”.

The blue PLA one is stretched in the Z direction to make it easier for the FDM printer to close the gaps (in Vase Mode).
The Orange ABS one is printed in normal mode, but than without infill and 0 top layers. Wall count is set to 2 layers. With the nozzle of 0.4 mm this makes the walls 0.8 mm thick. This was an attempt to make it easier for the FDM printer to close the walls without stretching the object to much in the Z direction. A disadvantage was that I had to do cleaning due to stringing. So I still prefer the “vase mode”option :-)

The Big blue One took 20 hours :-) and is 50 cm high.
This is file “flow vase3.stl” and is scaled 200% in the Z direction.
I experimented with light and that gave some illusive light effects.
I tried to capture it on photo..

Note: for making it easier on the FDM printer I made three different models.
“flow vase2.stl” & “flow vase3.stl” are the easiest.
“flow vase.stl” should be printed easy when Z is stretch out to 160%

FR
Deuxième version de la caméra aimantée pour Anycubic I3 avec un angle de vision déporté. La caméra suit toujours la progression de l'impression suivant l'axe Z mais elle est déportée vers le bas, offrant ainsi une meilleure vue de l'impression. Le support caméra présente un angle de 5° permettant la vue de la tête d'impression mais aussi le vue du lit.
Le couvercle est sécurisé par un blocage que vous pouvez débloquer en introduisant un tournevis. Il est possible de positionner l'ensemble à la hauteur souhaitée sur le support de moteur de l'imprimante.
Le boitier caméra est inchangé par rapport à la version 1.

ENG
Second version of the magnetic camera for Anycubic I3 with a better viewing angle. The camera always follows the progress of Z-axis printing, but is deported downward, providing a better view of the print. The camera support has an angle of 5 ° allowing the view of the print head but also the view of the bed.
The lid is secured by a lock that you can unlock by introducing a screwdriver. It is possible to position the assembly at the desired height on the printer motor bracket.
The camera case is unchanged from version 1.

description.text:
This is a DIY Qi charger case that I made for my new iPhone x. It is really compact and minimal in design. It utilizes a small and cheap qi charging circuit bought from eBay for less than 3 USD and a micro USB cable for 1 USD. See link down below.

The installation process is really simple,
1 Firstly take away all the support material and sand everything down if you want to paint it. 2. Desolder the led and mark its orientation so that you don't mix the colors up.
2 Then use really small screws (i don't have the exact measurement for them) to secure the PCB then solder on the led in the right position and cut excess leads off.
3 Then secure the charging coil by putting its wires in the cable channel and just put it in its place.
4 Lastly, put the lid on and screw it in place carefully.
5 Done, you now have your very own Qi charger for 3-4 USD depending on if you buy the cable or not and where you buy the circuit.

If you decide to make one of your own, pls share your new Qi chargers with the rest of us, cheers!

This one is the one I used and it is type 1: https://www.ebay.com/itm/Qi-Wireless-Charger-PCBA-Circuit-Board-Coil-Wireless-Charging-Pad-Micro-USB-DIY/371831176614?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=640820050412&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

Or this one but it uses a rectangle led: https://www.ebay.com/itm/1pc-Qi-Wireless-Charger-PCBA-Circuit-Board-With-Coil-Wireless-Charging-Gifts/122860109536?_trkparms=aid%3D222007%26algo%3DSIM.MBE%26ao%3D2%26asc%3D49924%26meid%3D94ac19a0c49d49fda5095261aace4bc3%26pid%3D100005%26rk%3D6%26rkt%3D6%26sd%3D371831176614%26itm%3D122860109536&_trksid=p2047675.c100005.m1851

Micro usb cable for 1 USD:
https://www.ebay.com/itm/3-6-10FT-Braided-Fast-Data-Sync-Charge-Cable-Cord-For-IOS-iPhone-Type-C-Android/162758143910?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=461792374615&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

description.text:
I found the Synta Shoe for Explore Scientific Handle (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2750850) here and liked it for my AR102. My goal was to mount my remote trigger green laser for quick aiming. (No modifications were made to this)

I found the Laser Holder for Telescope (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2301115) but wasn't happy with mounting that way. I preferred using the Picatinny rail and keeping it close to the scope, especially since it was hanging off the side of the scope and I didn't want to bump into it. I had printed a Vixen/Synta shoe with a Picatinny rail but it was missing the small square block that mates to some of these finder shoes and I wanted that to insure alignment after the initial setup so as not to have to check it each time.

I could have just added one to it but I really like the fit of "mianzel's" shoe on the Synta Shoe for the ES Handle I printed so I imported the Laser Holder for Telescope into Sketchup and removed the mount and riser from the foot. I then imported the Mini Picatinny Rail (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:293502) altered it a bit and mated it to the finder shoe. I printed it up and with a little bit of filing, it fits perfectly. The laser was almost perfectly aligned and only required a small amount of tweaking to line it up with the scope

title: Spark / Mavic Phone & Tablet Mount (GoPro Style)

description.text:
Spark / Mavic Phone & Tablet Mount (GoPro Style)

A tiltable universal lightweight mount to attach your phone or tablet to the DJI Spark / Mavic remote controller.

This mount uses a common GoPro clamp (GoPro screws are available on Ebay or Amazon). Using a GoPro clamp, the top mount can be easily tilted to any angle or be replaced by another mount. So you can switch from your phone to your tablet in seconds!

This mount uses a base part and a top mount. The base part snap-fits to the Spark / Mavic RC and provides a tight fit. Then choose a top mount that fits your device (several top mounts are included with the download). The top mounts are also designed to snap-fit your device.

VIDEO: https://youtu.be/jvjfAxv3QMk

SUPPORTED DEVICES YET:

  • Lenovo Tab3 8 Plus
  • Xiaomi Redmi Note 4 (Global)
  • iPhone 7 Plus
  • Galaxy S8+
  • More to come

If you need a top mount that fits to your device, just drop a comment and let me know:

  • Name of your device
  • Exact height of your device in mm (without any case!)
  • Depth (thickness) of your device in mm

PRINTING:

  • Print the files as provided
  • Infill 10-15%
  • Enable supports
  • Layer height: 0.1 - 0.3mm are fine

description.text:

high

Notes:

Works well in PLA or ABS.

Use a standard 2L bottle, cut an opening and small notch to reach around the stem.
Use the snap clip from another pool tool or Pool Pole Clip by thetazzbot.
Slip around the fruit and pull.
Set a bucket next to the tree and you can just drop the fruit into that and keep picking.

I used the thread specification drawing for PCO-1881-0 threads which appears to be what a lot of bottles in my area use. All the thread specs are available here: International Society of Beverage Technologists

title: Tevo Tornado X-Axis Pulley Wobble Fix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Tevo Tornado is using two 8mm ball bearings on a 7.7mm screw as an idler pulley for the X-axis belt. This causes the bushings to wobble with 0.6mm offset. This wobble together with the incorrect position may causes vibrations on the X-carriage. This fix properly aligns the bearings for the belt. You need a M6 x 25mm screw (can be longer) and a M6 lock nut to replace the M8 screw. Tap the parts with the M6 screw first from the opposite side and align the notch with the bottom of the bracket. Lower the extrusion multiplier if the parts don't fit. This is a tight fit on design, the right extrusion multiplier is key to print this correctly. The Fusion 360 .f3d file is included if you need to make any adjustments.

Parts needed:
M6 x 25mm screw (Din912, Din7984, ISO7380)
M6 lock nut

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20-0.30

Notes:

This is a tight fit on design, the right extrusion multiplier is key to print this correctly. Lower the extrusion multiplier if the parts don't fit.

comments.text: It appears the outer race of the bearing and spacer will be rubbing on each other creating excessive and unwanted friction. Don't you think your spacer should only be up against the inner race?
comments.author: NitroTech

comments.text: The bearings are free floating on the 10mm spacer (Tornado_X-Axis_Pulley-2.stl) and are hardly touching the flange of the bearing (the flange doesn't rotate either). I think this is the best compromise between easy print ability and stability.
comments.author: NitroTech

author: JohannesBerlin

description.text:
Nicknamed the L-plate because that's what you have to display on your car when learning to drive in NZ, this is a variant of the bashguard that allows you to remove the horizontal standoff in the camera cage and replace it with this part. the upper edge has been given a big structure boost and a notch has been created to allow the camera angle to be reduced from the minimum of 35° to around 15° with a 2.1mm lens.

Please note that this part will not be as strong as the aluminium standoff and is intended for lower speed flight flight only, if you are a competent flyer or flying in more open areas, please download the standard bashguard that fits around the horizontal standoff for maximum strength and protection.

Big thanks again to Cluf for the test prints and Images!

title: SOPORTE PLAFÓN LED. (LED CEILING LIGHT SUPPORT?)

description.text:
Como podéis ver en las imágenes en la terraza de mi piso tenía un plafón de cristal antiguo, este llevaba desde hace mas de 25 años. Como esta luz se enciende de muy tarde en tarde pues nunca la hemos cambiado. Hace un tiempo compre un pequeño plafón de led de 15x15 cm y lo tenía dando vueltas y enganchado a una base de lampara que me sobró de otro proyecto pero sin llegar a usarla. Se me ocurrió diseñar esta base y colocarla en la terraza. Ha quedado simple pero chula y da una luz de escándalo.
Decir que le he puesto unos 8 mm de grosor en los lados donde se apoyan los clips del plafón para que no se rompiera el soporte. Viene mejor ponerle 5 o 6 mm, ya que tiene unos tornillos y al hacer el diseño no los tuve en cuenta, un toque con la "Dremel" (en mi caso una BlackDecker) y encaje perfecto.
Para no tener que hacer agujeros en los azulejos he decidido ponerla con cinta de doble cara de la ultrafuerte (ver imagen) (esta la he usado para colgar cuadros en el cuarto de baño y llevan más de tres años colgados sin caerse).
Deciros que han sido 9 horas y 59 minutos lo que ha tardado en imprimirse, a 40 mm/s.

Traducción Google:

As you can see in the images on the terrace of my flat, I had an antique glass ceiling panel, which I had been wearing for more than 25 years. As this light comes on very late in the afternoon, we have never changed it. Some time ago I bought a small 15x15 cm led panel and I had it spinning around and hooked to a lamp base that I had left over from another project but without using it. It occurred to me to design this base and place it on the terrace. It has been simple but cool and gives a light of scandal.
To say that I have put about 8 mm thick on the sides where the clips of the panel rest so that the support does not break. It is better to put 5 or 6 mm, since it has some screws and when doing the design I did not take them into account, a touch with the "Dremel" (in my case a BlackDecker) and perfect fit.
To avoid having to make holes in the tiles I decided to put it with double-sided tape from the ultra strong (see image) (I used it to hang pictures in the bathroom and have been hanging for more than three years without falling).
Tell them that it has been 9 hours and 59 minutes that it has taken to print, at 40 mm / s.

description.text:
So my CR10 suffers from being in a fairly dark room, and I was having to use a torch for setting up and inspecting prints. I had a bit of a search around and found some under cabinet LED strips (30cm / 300mm) and designed a frame to sit on top of the CR10 frame and hold the strips, this lights the bed perfectly. My tolerances are a little off, so when you clip the lights into the frame, it bends slightly, but this gives a pleasant curve and light dispersal, that's my excuse and I'm sticking to it.
Work in progress, I will develop this to have a cable tidy type clip to keep the wires out of the way of the moving parts.

title: ANET A8 120V Power Cable Wire Clamp for stress relief

description.text:
The photo shows a wire clamp to hold and provide stress relief for the 120V power cord to the Anet A8 power supply. The clamp is quick to build and requires no other hardware since it uses existing screws on the printer.

The clamp is mounted to two Z motor housing bolts next to the power supply. The part uses all the remaining screw length beyond the nuts and is thin, about 1.6 mm.

Disassemble one screw at a time after securing the nut. Using a piece of tape, secure the nut's position in the motor housing by applying tape to it and pressing firmly on the tape to hold the nut in position, then unscrew the first screw. Align the clamp and insert the first screw and reassemble. Then move the cable into position, it will snap firmly into the clamp opening. Make sure to have slack on the cable from the clamp to the power supply.

Screw in the second bolt. Done!

Printer:

ANET A8 - Prusa clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I use 0.8 walls, 100% flow, and 60mm print speed at 200C head and 60C bed with 3M Platinum Saferelease tape. The brim I like to use is 10 mm which clearly shows me the stresses on the part when cooling.

For part removal I like to let the bed cool to room temp. Then take a single edge razor blade and carefully work under the raft and get under the part. The plastic tape is easily cut if the blade ever digs down. I like to bend the cold raft in both directions, sometimes hearing a snapping sound, before ripping it from the part. I use an xacto knife to clean up the part.

description.text:
I created this clip for the IKEA Sortera bin to stop our 14 months old little toddler from opening and throwing everything inside out on the floor.

Just snap the clip onto the lid from the bottom en gently force it over the edge on the top. When you close the lid it automatically prevents the lid from being easily opened.

To open the lid just pull/bend the lid close to the clip/clips towards you and it opens easily. You can also slide the clips to the center of the lid to unlock it.

Based on the Tronxy X1 or the Hictop ender2 style printers, I built this with a 1 meter Z in mind. The heat bed has a wheel in each corner for maximum stability, it uses a bed from an Anet A8, 220mm x 220mm with 208mm mounting hole pitch. The mototrs were from the same machine but most Nema 17 motors should do. The Z axis is 2060 extrusion with the 60mm in the X axis for maximum arm support. The arm is 2040 but it should work OK with 2020.
2020 extrusion 2x 220mm, 2x 480mm
2040 extrusion 1x 400mm
2060 extrusion as long as required for Z travel
All V Slot extrusion

2040 tensioner - This was built to take a tension roller from an Anycubic delta printer but a pair of F623ZZ should fit too.

Carriage roller support and brace - Print 2 roller supprts and one brace, these join together with M4 screws. There is no means of manual bed levelling as I rely on Marlin auto bed level, this means the heat bed can be fixed down solid on some type insulating spacer for better rigidity.

Hotend mount, brace and X wheel spacers - Print 1 mount, 1 brace and 6 spacers. The spacers fit each side of the rollers. There is no adjustment for a good fit on the 2040 but mine fitted perfectly first time, otherwise i would have slotted the bottom roller mounting hole to get good tension. There is a 18mm probe mount included with enough space to fit a part cooling fang.

X motor mount - I havent tried this part as I found a flat metal Nema mount so used that but
this design should work fine.

Z Runners front and back - These need to be printed strong, lots of perimeters and layers, I used the most rigid PLA I could find, this is to reduce flex of the X axis beam in the Y direction. 6 Z wheel spacers needed too. There were 2 wheel tensioners on this design but it compromised the overall rigidity of the carriage so I made the front runner solid.

For the Y axis tensioner I used the popular idig3D tensioner https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2020468 Print and extra knob for the X axis.

The base can be made from anything that is super rigid. I used a 1//2" Paxolin board as I had some off cut at work. MDF or ply should work if thick enough.

This is still very much a work in progress, and as yet its untested but it looks promising.

https://youtu.be/SoiLshKbqNc

title: PVC Pipe Holder for 1.5inch Ball Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
::Still a work in progress and untested! Beware! Needed to mount my DIY LED lamp for my Native Kayak. Where I'm from, there are a large number of Native Mariner Propel owners. The most common diy lamp for the yak involves a 22mm Outer Diameter PVC pipe which is "pushed" into the side slots. I'm upgrading to a Native Slayer Propel and would like to make use of the tracks/rails that it provides. I will secure a 1.5" ball ram mount to the track and secure this object on the mount. (The ball mount is used so that I can tilt the lamp over the water while fishing or to make it flush with the kayak when stored)
  • The screw hole is currently slightly smaller than that needed for a 1/4". This is intentional but I will be making it larger in another version so that the object can bend easily.
  • v1 is incredibly thick, and in some places, unnecessarily so. It is also nigh on impossible to bend by hand (undesirable as I need to tighten it against the mount)
  • v1 has been tested against a 22mm pipe. With some finishing, it will fit very nicely.
  • v2 reduces plastic use and also introduces more empty spaces in the "grip" area, hopefully so that it can bend.
  • Neither versions have been tested against the ram mount yet.
  • It is my intention to print every layer as a solid layer. This has the added bonus of simplifying any possible derivatives.
Unless you're making a mould, you should probably print this with solid layers, every layer. Just in case.

Electronic components are listed on Gitbub:
https://github.com/ArduinoHannover/Maiskolben/blob/master/Maiskolben_THT/README.md

screw:

2x Pan-Head flat head screw 3x12 (Attachment of the power plug)

The holes in the housing must always be drilled.

description.text:
Remix of spaxi's CR-10 Fan Mod with feet.

Because I needed just the feet (for better PSU airflow) I changed the STL to fit my needs.

How is it mounted?

  1. Remove the base plate.
  2. Unscrew the rubber feet
  3. Put the base plate together with a pair of the feet (front and back) on.
  4. Screw them gently (eventually you will need washers in order to not crack the plastics).
  5. Take the rubber feet and put them in the provided space.
  6. Have fun!

Enginseers are highly trained members of the Cult Mechanicus and are dedicated to the maintenance of Imperial technology. Through many years of study they have gained the knowledge of the rituals and litanies that form the body of machine lore, as well as a deep understanding of the more practical disciplines of mechanics and electronics. In this role they serve across the galaxy, often in harm's way, as they will be called on to make repairs on the battlefield as well as in the workshop. They are a common sight on battlefields with large numbers of armoured vehicles, and are often accompanied by a retinue of servitors for assistance or protection. Although most Guardsmen revere their vehicles enough not to risk annoying an Enginseer by 'tinkering,' the modification of vehicles to fulfill a certain need is inevitable, much to the chagrin of any Enginseers present. Enginseer contingents are also included in the mighty Titan Legions and the crews of the massive warships of the Imperial Navy, allowing them to perform emergency repairs in the heat of battle.

Despite the respect they usually command among the units they are seconded to, Enginseers are not held in high regard among the Cult Mechanicus itself as their skills seldom contribute to The Quest for Knowledge. As a result of their overwhelmingly practical knowledge, they are often viewed as lowly but necessary cogs in the workings of the Cult. Enginseers make use of robotic arm augmentations known as Mechadendrites that are connected to their central nervous system via the spine. They are used to help the enginseer in repair operations, heavy lifting and for self defence.
