description.text:
I use gauze 4x4 sponges (12 ply gauze compress) for all sorts of 3d printing tasks. In combination with an eyedropper filled with 91% isopropyl alcohol, they strip hairspray off the build plate perfectly! A couple of droppers-full of ABS/Acetone slurry on the build plate, spread around with a 4x4 saturated with acetone, and you'll need a sharpened 1-1/2" putty knife to get the print unstuck. I've actually pulled a divot of borosilicate glass out of my print bed using that method.

This dispenser is sized for the 200 count package available on Amazon for less than $10. Dimples in the back for hot glue and/or magnets (I wanted to stick it to the side of my refrigerator.)

By harnessing the power of the atom, and using your advanced knowledge of medical imaging, radiology, physics, and nuclear safety, you too may be able to construct this nuclear powered desktop computed tomography (CT) scanner. comments.text: Thus might be useful if you were not already aware http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lock-in_amplifierhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L...
comments.author: wildseyed

comments.text: When I was designing the detector I'd thought about using a phase lock amplifier, too (we used to use them on the spectrometers in the lab), and then it occurred to me that to modulate the signal you'd basically need something like a thick lead pinwheel spinning at 10,000 RPM beside the detector, which is impractical (unless there's a better way to modulate the signal when dealing with high energy particles?  I don't have a lot of experience at these energies).  The detector used here is actually really well done, and should be detecting the ~30keV emissions from the Barium-133 at around 10% efficiency, which is pretty incredible.  Background detections/noise with an external comparator that brings the detection threshold down to ~30keV is about 20 cpm, and the energy of the source around 12cm away is ~550cpm, so the system actually has a really reasonable SNR if you're willing to wait about 60 seconds for the statistics to work out and subtract off the background baseline.  Since there are so few photons to begin with, it's largely a matter of time and doing the detections in parallel, I think, that will ultimately decrease scan time.  Thanks for the suggestion!

title: Hypercube Bearing Supported Z Axis Leadscrew Motor Mount

description.text:
Hi,

this is a Z axis motor mount for a bearing supported lead screw. It prevents the lead screw from bouncing caused by springy couplers. I merged two parts to get a good mount to the frame and the bearing post. See credits for the sources. You need 608 bearings for the threaded rod.

It works fine for me and I have upgraded my z quality by this. You should also support your lead screw on the top. Additionally, an anti-backlash nut improves the z banding furthermore.

Doublecheck your mounting direction before printing. In contrast to the original design it is mounted in reverse.

author: JonoGreyBeard

description.text:
with this design follow the described order for proper installation.
  • slide both hot ends into the slots
  • snap 1 side of the fan shroud onto the collar just above the top cooling fins.
  • rotate the fan shroud until the second extruder snaps into place.
  • put the clamp over the top of the nozzles to lock them in place.
  • tighten down the ptc connectors all the way and cut the extra plastic flange off of the outside, this is a tight fit and is required to get these to not bind inside the effector plate
    Image
  • insert screws through head before installation of the fans because they will block the holes, i use a couple tiny drops of superglue instead of screws to hold the 30mm fans in place.
    Image
  • install the nozzles so they are parallel with the Y axis (6 holes in the effector plate this makes offset in firmware easiest).
  • if shimming is required just loosen the two screws on the nozzle that needs adjustment and insert shim between effector plate and clamp.
    let me know if any additional info is needed.

comments.author: chashubert

comments.text:
The Delta Printer on its own can cause issues. If one setting isn't exactly correct you can
get undesirable results even with a single extruder. Adding a second extruder to a non-perfectly
calibrated machine will just drive the user mad. That being said, if you got your settings
dialed in, the nozzles perfectly adjusted evenly with each other you will have
no issues with adding the second extruder.
I feel like my machine is mechanically sound, and the issues I am
running into are software related. I've
gotten back into slic3r because of kiss’s lost developer and lack of dual
material development/support. Simplify3d
creator looks promising yet I haven’t forked over the dough to buy it yet.

I'm mainly looking to add the second extruder to do supports using PVA or some or easily soluable liquid.  Thanks for the tip on Simpliy3d.

description.text: This is the first part with others to follow. The holes are supposed to be 1/8th inch but they print a little small. Once I am done adding parts I'll roll them all into one. The holes are for 1/8th inch acrylic rods.

Three variations on a push-fit fan guard, fits the Titan Aero 40mm fan.

Minimal low profile, larger more styled design and a variarion on the last with a pad for the x-axis endstop since that is how mine sits on my A8.

A fun little flying model helicopter. As simple as it gets! Two propellers held apart by a body and a paper clip, and powered by a rubber band. Quick to print and build and really easy to get it flying. I made the propeller design as an upright flat so that it prints quickly without needing support. The pitch on the propellers is added after printing by heating and bending. http://youtu.be/ShZxD3JiJlY

I made the propellers with ABS but PLA should also be fine (but more likely to break if the helicopter crashes into anything hard).  Keep the body light - I used 2 perimeters and 20% fill.  
The propellers are very thin - I used a 2mm brim to help keep the ends stuck to the print bed.  They are 200mm long so should just fit diagonally on a 150mm square print area.  I found that the small holes closed up on the first layer and I needed to open them up with a 1mm drill.  Note there is a second hole just off-centre that goes about half way thru the hub.  
Unfold a paper clip to use as the propeller shafts.  You could use piano wire (from a model suppliers store) if you want stiffer, more durable wire.  Paper clip wire works OK for this model but it does bend easily in use.  One straightened paper clip gives enough wire for two propellers.  Bend 3mm on one end thru 180° to make a hook that will fit into the off-centre hole when the wire is fitted to the propeller. Fit a shaft into each propeller.  You can add a drop of glue to keep it there but it shouldn't really be necessary.   
Now you need to bend the propellers.  I used a fan heater to warm the centre section.  If your propellers are PLA you could trickle boiling water over the centre section.  When warmed - twist the narrow section between the hub and the wider part of each blade.  Twist about 60°.  Once you have both blades twisted, do the same with the second propeller - taking care to ensure that the second propeller is a mirror image of the first one.  They need to be opposite so that they will both lift when spinning in opposite directions.  I used a belt sander to radius the square corners of the propellers but you can skip this step if you are keen to get flying.  
Slip the propeller shafts thru the holes in the ends of the body and bend the shafts to make hooks to suit the rubber band.  Fit a rubber band or two and wind it up - holding one propeller and the body and then spinning the loose propeller.  To launch - decide which way up it needs to be (see the video clip) and let it go.  Experiment with the strength and number of rubber bands and number of turns to get the best out of it.  Be warned - flying it indoors may mark ceilings and walls.  Flying it outdoors it can easily end up on the roof.  
Have fun.

author: 87squirrels

remixed_from.author: Lochemage
remixed_from.title: Loches Z Axis Upgrade for MakerGear Prusa Mendel

description.text:
This is my take on the bowdens mount for dual extruding on the MakerGear Prusa (along with my previous upgrade on the Z-Axis).
I've taken the 2 Extruder Mod by dob71 and redesigned the hotend mount for easier assembly.  I have also resized everything to fit 1.75 filament.
The X-Carriage has a wider opening to give enough room for both hotends.
Just as a note, I have been using this setup for about 2 months now (as of Aug 02, 2012).  I've mostly used it as a single extruder because I haven't gotten a concrete way of generating dual-extrusion gcode yet (working on it).  The print quality isn't perfect, but it isn't bad either (in fact, the pictures you see are all from a second set printed while using my first set).  I ended up using a slow retraction of 10mm to remove the blobbing and nozzle drip.

Parts needed:
  • Four M5 Nuts
  • Two 1.75 filament guide tubes.
  • Two MakerGear hotends.
  • Two M6x30 Bolts.
  • Various other nuts and bolts that are either already part of your printer or used to mount your extruder blocks.
  • One Printed Hotend Joint.
  • One Printed Hotend Mount.
  • One X-Bowden Carriage.
  • Two Printed Shoulder Mounts.
    • The two shoulder mounts go on the top of the printer on both ends of the two top horizontal rods, they should replace the two bar clamps that hold the top of the Z-axis smooth rods. Take the filament tubes and screw an M5 nut to the ends of each tube. One end of each tube goes to the shoulders and the other ends go to the hotend joint, each should have an M5 nut trap that is used to hold the tube in place. The two hotends should slide into the hotend mount and through the opening of the X-Carriage. The hotend joint should fit over the tops of the two hotends and they should all screw together with two M6 bolts. As for generating gcode for dual extrusion, I have been working on splicing software for this. It allows you to import multiple gcode files, assign your intended extruder to each one, and output a final spliced gcode file that will print your final product! It is still in beta stages right now. Check out some screenshots of the latest splicer here: https://bitbucket.org/Lochemage/lochegsplicer/wiki/Screenshots. You can also download the latest windows installer here: https://bitbucket.org/Lochemage/lochegsplicer/downloads. Enjoy!

comments.text:
Hello , i have made your configuration about extra height on prusa mendel 2. I am using greg's extruder but now x axis is limited to 100mm and before it was 180mm. I am thinging to change extruder to mk8 ,but i have see you have used bowden extruder.
What is your opinion about bowden extruder ,is it deserve this mod, do you have the same good result as mk8 extruder, is it easier to clean it, is it a benefit that you have less height on x axis?
I don't care about two extruders (but it wouldn't be bad). Because of the long distance from the extruder motor until hot end , i suppose there will be some different , i don't know what it would be.
Thank you
comments.author: Mendel_2

comments.text: I'm currently using a bowdens, but if I had the choice, I would stick with the direct.  Bowden works, but it is a lot more complicated to setup and print with, and there are limitations on how you can print things.  As for weight, I wouldn't worry about that on the prusa, it can handle weight.
comments.author: Mendel_2

comments.text: Does your x axis belt still fit?  Thinking about this mod and your vertical mod but I'm unsure about your ends that move the x axis belt.
comments.author: NovaOne

comments.text: When you compare the belt length of the original against the Z axis upgrade, there is a little more distance to cover for the belt.  So if you clipped the belt to fit exactly, then it will end up too short for the upgrade.  Otherwise, the default belt length provided by the kit is long enough.

Of course, you could always modify it to fit one of those push fit connectors, which are also nice.

remixed_from.author: styk
remixed_from.title: Hictop Y axis end limit switch stationary mount

title: Hictop Y axis stationary adjustable end stop

description.text: The original configuration on the Hictop 3dp-17 has the Y axis end stop switch mounted on the bed assembly. The connection failed on mine so when i tore things down to repair the switch ( broken solder connection) I decided to make it easier to access down the road. I designed a one piece bracket that moved the switch to a stationary position by the Y axis motor. I noticed the zero position was off the bed a bit so I remixed the design to make it adjustable. I made it to fit the original 5mm hardware and also 4 mm hardware.

This is a stand designed to hold (6) 10ml roller bottles, like the type often used for essential oils. The bottles I made these for had a 20mm diameter. The slots allow for a secure hold without being tight enough to damage any labeling on the bottles.

I had Y-Up set as the default orientation in Fusion 360 when I modeled this, so you will have to rotate it in your slicer so that the base is down.

print_settings.Notes:: For the beginners: Follow the pics for printing position.

description.text:
Hello everybody!
I've bought a professional knife set at the last Black Friday at Amazon store:
http://amzn.com/B002ZCKIBM
the knive set comes without block so I created one.
I inspired from this awesome idea: https://www.instructables.com/id/Knife-Block/ and I remixed the project for FDM printers.

I wolud speak about safety because this thing will be at home and the knives may be dangerous, so it's great idea if you follow three important steps below:
1) Use magnets as described on the project, you can find here:
https://www.amazon.it/Magnetastico%C2%AE-neodimio-frigorifero-permanente-interattiva/dp/B00Z7YVU8A
2) Use rubber pads, print them with TPU95 or other rubber filament
3) Create the ballast, I hope you can create it with milling machine, the one in my project have a weight of 2.3Kg

You need these hardware:

Phillips flat head self tapping screw 4.8mm x 22mm: 2pcs
Phillips flat head self tapping screw 5.5mm x 25mm: 2pcs
Neodymium magnets 8mm x 3mm: 4 pcs

Check everything else on the PDF and pics.

author: edixot

description.text:
A remix of the Led Bridge Lamp by Opossums :

  • bolted version
  • foot parts printable on Flashforge Dreamer

The wonderfull Led Bridge Lamp made by designer Opossums
(see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1639224) makes me think of
the Eiffel Tower.

The original design features relatively large 'tabs', marked 'Left'
and 'Right' on the segment sides.
These tabs are the reason the side- and top-parts of the segment need
to be printed with supports.

I was looking for a design that could be printed without supports
and came up with this alternative version :

  • CURVED and STRAIGHT SEGMENTS :

    • No more supports needed, no post-printing cleanup work, less
      material wasted.
    • Segment sides Left and Right are now identical, and so are top
      panels A and B - resulting in a more simple design.
    • You WILL need a handfull of M2 bolts and (nylon lock) nuts to
      inter-assemble the segments :
      M2x10mm : 3 per segment
      M2x6mm : 1 per curved segment
      M2x20mm : 4 per foot
    • You will need a long, thin screwdriver to assemble the segments.
    • Segments can be assembled without glue (except for the LED
      channels and top-to-side of course). If you use glue, the bolts
      will keep the parts in place while the glue dries.
    • Base-plates 'mama' and 'papa' were redesigned to fit the M2 bolts
    • Straight segments were modified as well to match the bolted
      assembly method.
    • The LED channel sides have been rounded - somehow this prints
      cleaner on a Flashforge Dreamer at a cost of a little more PLA.
      Try it out or use the original flat sided LED channels.

  • BRIDGE FOOT :

    • The Foot parts are too large for a Flashforge Dreamer printer-
      platform so I resized the Foot Base, Center and Side parts.
    • The Foot Base now fits inside the Foot Center part
    • Foot parts Center, Cap and Height Extension can also be bolted
      together using M2 bolts
    • New design of the Foot Side part to use less filament.
    • Added small tabs to the top of the Foot Side-panels.
      These tabs fit in the bottom of the Foot Cap, so you don't
      have to glue the Foot Sides to the Foot Center part.
    • As I did not need electronics in the Foot Base, I added a
      ballast-tray and glued 2 layers of M8 nuts and some lead
      airgun pellets in between those and so added some 500gr of weight
      per foot.

    Sketchup files are included so you can modify parts if you need
    some sort of PCB-board on top of the Foot Base ballast tray,
    or if you use a different size/type of power inlet or switch.

Enjoy!

Printed on Flashforge Dreamer in PLA, no supports, no raft.
First layer max. speed 10mm/s, 30% infill - standard print resolution.

UPDATE 2018 02 14
I just uploaded a new version of the base that should make it easier to fit all the inkpots. Hardback-1_1-Base removes the inside fillets on the long sides at the bottom of the well. This opens a good bit more space, which in turn gives you more room for the inkpots. The original base should still work fine. I find if the cover doesn't sit flush at first, shaking the base back and forth gets the inkpots to settle.

Now back to your regularly scheduled program

Here is space for 5 hardbacks inside a hardback that fits inside Hardback the game. Of course, there is also room for all the rest of the pieces.

I backed Hardback through Kickstarter and we enjoy playing it. While the box is quite compact, I was still looking for some way to jettison the baggies and make it even easier to set up.

So, here you have it.

The case is reminiscent of a hardback and the inside has room for ink, ink remover, all the hardback player tokens, and a slot for the first player ink well token. The larger compartment is for the ink tokens (black) and the smaller is for the ink remover tokens (white).

Setup is easy. Just take off the cover, select your hardback colors and deploy the first player token. You are now all set. Draw from the ink and ink remover bins as necessary.

The case is just wide enough to fit between the manual and prestige tracker board. It will also fit when the player cards are on either side, but the optimal fit is when the player cards are shoved to the opposite end. Additionally, this is just thick enough to comfortably fit with sleeved cards.

NOTE: The first player marker has a distinctive "arch". When placing it in the slot, be sure to have the center of the "arch" pointing upward. Basically the feather end should be near the hardback slots and the inkwell towards the ink remover bin. Otherwise, you'll have to tip the base upside down to get the first player marker out.

NOTE 2: I'm offering to print these for anyone in need. Visit my Etsy shop if you are interested. Store All The Bits

remixed_from.title: Oblique nib holder for Copperplate calligraphy

description.text:
This is an oblique pen nib holder for left-handers, not for a particular lettering style, just to write more naturally with a left-handed pen holding style.

pen0002a fits speedball 512 and like "wide" nibs, pen0003a fits speedball 99 and like "narrow" nibs. The OpenSCAD source is adjustable, find it at http://burningsmell.org/3d/oblique-pen/

Incorporates the handle from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2226446 and good suggestions from Theremar.

It has a 45 degree oblique and a ten-degree downward adjustment plus twist to meet the paper closer to dead on. It's intended for southpaws who learned under-writer or side-writer penholding styles. YMMV.

This is a clone of the Artifact Retaliator barrel spacer that holds the barrels of the sealed breech kit. You glue the spacer in and then slide your barrel through (different tolerances may require some finagling on your end though).
The Artifact version is also compatible with the Worker Prophecy sealed breech kit, though you will have to install a grub screw, glue the barrel in, or something of the sort so it won't be pushed out (it has no knurling like Artifact).

The 17/32" brass version is for sleeper/brass breeches for the retaliator. Helps a lot when spacing and essentially eliminates the hotglue/tape mess that you usually have to do. You have to glue the barrel in/drill for a grub screw however.

Tolerances may vary based on printer used.

print_settings.Notes:: 3 perimeters works well

description.text:
I was looking for something to impress my brother-in-law for Christmas. He always seemed inordinately pleased with the gear systems I had given him before, so I was looking for something more elaborate. I liked the asymmetric planetary gears by faggahz, and the eccentrically cycloidal drive model by otvinta3d, but neither seemed to quite do it. So of course the logical thing to do is to connect them together. I made extensive use if the customizable involute spur gear by artanian and would like to say I made it through logical design processes and that it worked perfectly the first time, but that would not be correct. So exactly how much of this did I do? I designed the transmission and the support structure, both of which I thought came out pretty well.

I of course designed this to print on my machine, which does outside measurements pretty well, but tends to make inside measurements a little small. Since the tolerances on everything are a little tight, you may want so subtly adjust the size of a few components if it doesn’t work for you. Ring 2a, Hold 5, and all the axles are good candidates for this. It uses 6 #4 x 0.5 inch flat head bolts with nuts to hold the supports to the base. You could glue them in place, but then you wouldn’t be able to take it apart if it needed repair.

Assembly tips:

Adjust the contact layer to spread as little as possible while maintaining a good bond (this is a nuisance to clean off gears).
Print one of most things but two of “Support5,” “Clip4,” and “2_peg” (so a total of four pegs).
Make the planetary gears first; these fit most closely and it will tell you if you have to adjust sizes. They should all snap in at once. They should also be capable of rotating without the square support (Hold5). There are several ways they can be inserted, but only one were the support lines up with all the holes (the side of the support against the build surface goes away from the gears). The pegs join all the gears to the support except “Planet 7” (the small one).
To make the transmission, insert “Small_axle_ext” through the 10 tooth gear (pliers may be necessary). Insert the washer one end and the same end through "Hold5" into "Planet7." Insert the plain end of “Bottom axle 1” into the 27 tooth gear (I glued it, but it may not be necessary). Engage the 27 and 10 tooth gear the drop “Brace 2a” over both axles (snap it onto the smaller one). Place “Spacer1” on the larger axle.
Place “Wheel2” between the two “Support5’s” (the washer-like bearings go on the inside). Place this assembly over “Bottom_axle1” and secure with “Clip4.” The full assembly can then be attached to the base with the 6 nuts and bolts. Insert the plain end of “Top axle 1” into “Spinner 3,” glue if desired. Engage “Pinion2” to “Wheel2” and pass the axle through it. Secure the axle with the other clip. Place “Bridge3” over the protruding struts of the supports and ring gear (should be a good friction fit). And you should be done.

http://youtu.be/3UGVun5kG5w

This is a spring spacer/spring rest for the Worker Prophecy "25N Spring" for retaliators, retalicons, and reconciliators. I would only recommend this with expanded plunger tubes so the extra volume can be utilized effectively.

It fits inside the retaliator/recon stock attachment point. For retaliator shells, the original spring rest will have to be dremeled away entirely so the spring can rest on this part.

This part has the spring under a sizeable amount of precompression and the springload is held by the screws holding the stock attachment block on. I replaced the stock ones with longer screws and it's holding fine. Alternatively/additionally, you can put screws through the stock/stock block diagonally like the Prophecy blaster itself.

You essentially need a metal boltseld/really rigid boltsled for this to work. Tolerances may vary, this is what my printer was able to make. The part should fit pretty snugly inside the stock attachment block and the spring should not rub (much) on the inside.

description.text:
This y-tensioner Part was designed to be used with the Tronxy X3A bed upgrade parts. It is made to be used with the carriage and end cap and thumb handle from and big shouts out to IDig3D's parts on the upgraded y-tensioner ( thingiverse.com/thing:2021999 )
This part has been designed to be used with the bed upgrade kit ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2714569 ), for and in the same awesome on the fly adjustment capacity way that IDig3D designed into his pats.
As the other y-tensioner with the bed upgrade kit did not provide a dynamic way of adjusting to my liking like IDig3D's did. This tensioner has been designed to use the original m4 8mm screws and t-nuts. It was designed with to be used with, and big shouts out to kencam's rod holders ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185364 ).

The Bed upgrade has been modified from and big shouts outs to Thundrfuk's remix ( thingiverse.com/thing:2714569 ) of and also big shouts out to kencam with the original bed part ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2185364 ) to attempt to center the belt mounting position so when pulling the vibration should be minimal, and the belt mounting hooks have been elongated to accommodate for the new flipped position of the motor and pulley, so the belt can line up nicely with these new flipped positions.

The Y-end stop is used if you use the original length 6mm wide belt when you use my y-motor mount flipped for this upgrade ( thingiverse.com/thing:2765629 ) and mount the motor on the inside of the frame. Doing this cause the bed not to go as far back as it did originally, but as long as your not using the entire length of the bed printing in the center will still work. I'm not sure or haven't spent any time in the setting of the black box to adjust for this yet, or in the settings of repeater host for some adjustment for this yet, which I'm thinking there must be in there somewhere on both. This was done out of my cheapness on not to buy a longer new belt for this upgrade to work. perhaps buying a longer belt and leaving the motor on the outside of frame would be best overall. at that point you can use the End stop from Thundrfuk's parts kit ( thingiverse.com/thing:2714569 ). This y-end stop was designed to use the original m4 8mm screws and t-nuts.
** OFF SET SOLVED *** -- Turns out, to adjust the "Home Offset" on a printer all you need to do is issue a few G-code commands. While your repeater host is connected to the printer, in the manual control tab issue the command ( M206 Y10 ), this sets the home offset for the Y axis at 10mm. you probably don't need to change the X, but I did because when I clicked home and the head went to the middle, well it never was quite the middle. so I also did M206 X15 . Then you want to do a M500 to save the new settings. And you can then see your new home offsets with the command M503. And now its all Good!

description.text:
This is a stand to hold your Handpresso while it is making your espresso.

It saves you the hard work of standing around holding it for a minute or so, leaving you free to eat your cornflakes while it's dispensing.

It's customisable - of most use is probably the cup height parameter, which creates a taller or shorter model depending on how tall your espresso cups are.

STLs are presented setup for my 65mm-high cups.

Notes:

The model is oriented to print on its back, without any supports.

I use a skirt just to check build plate levelling before it gets to the print proper, but that's nothing special. I used 20% infill, but there's no particular reason for that.

This model works by constructing the stand, then "subtracting" a model of the Handpresso from it, to provide the neat fit. The stand is a series of (slightly fancy) cubes, and the triangular feet are constructed using the hull feature.

description.text:
Spinning Yin Yang Logo/Symbol, Taichi, Key Chain

The yin-yang logo (aka, symbol, diagram, or Taichi Tu) is an interesting geometric structure with a touch of traditional oriental philosophy. It is full of circles, lending itself to an appealing 3D design project. One can make the basic shape first and then gradullay add more features. In this design, I made the inner disc spinnable, thus adding an extra layer to the design challenge.

It has a diameter of about 46mm and is 4.8mm thick. It prints well at a resolution between 0.1mm and 0.2mm in one piece. Have fun!

author: lgbu

title: K40 Laser Drag Chain For Air Assist

description.text:
The end pieces that come with the chain hold it above the beam path no matter where you are cutting. I print at 100% infill for strength. I printed everything in PLA.
Print
1 Stationary End Piece
1 Moving End Piece
1 Angle Bracket
4 Nuts
4 Bolts
~ 25 Links

You will need a drill to attach the Stationary End Piece to the back of the K40. Careful not to destroy your tube when you punch a hole in the steel. You may be able to get it to stick with double sided tape but I wanted it very secure. You will see multiple colors in my picture but it is all printed in PLA. Before installing the chain I exercised it back and forth in my hands for a few minutes to wear down any rough spots in the print. It really helped to make it move more smoothly.

Download DragChainEntire.rsdoc and edit in DesignSpark Mechanical if you need to change anything. Its free and fairly beginner friendly.

author: tedder

description.text:
Increase the operating range of your wifi signal by up to 2x with this hack! You can put this simple yagi antenna on a regular wifi antenna to make it more directional, and boost the signal by up to 6dB.

No 3D printer required to make one of these! This 'thing' is a derivation of a design shared by Brian Beezley, so if you are interested to know more about how it works, or want to build one without a 3D printer, be sure to check out his post here: http://ham-radio.com/k6sti/wifiyagi.htm

The original work was also featured on Hackaday: https://hackaday.com/2017/01/24/a-simple-yagi-antenna-for-your-wi-fi-router/

Printer:

Cetus 3D

This print has multiple pieces:

  • the body
  • the nut
  • and, the finger grips

After printing, the finger grips are to be glued into the body with super glue, making sure that the trapazoidal end is upward, and the taper is inward.

While the glue is drying, you can cut the wire for the two parasitic elements. Cut a 2" and a 2-1/4" piece of 14ga copper. Straighten them, mark the mid-point, and insert the short piece closest to the antenna axis and the longer piece into the furthest location. Align the midpoint to a common reference for each element.

That's pretty much all! Now, pick a cinch nut that fits your antenna best, screw it on to the body, and mount to your wifi antenna for increased range! Be sure to experiment with the direction it is pointing and the height along the antenna axis.

title: Big Shot GT8000 Blazer Torch stand / base (Glorious Jofo-Albar)

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/56EFY2hay0Y

Printed with 0.2mm layer height on a CR-10S with a 0.4mm nozzle in standard PLA @ 200 degrees C on a sanded mirror bed heated to 70 degrees C.

My torch's base broke a while back and this thing keeps falling over, which is not a great feature of a top-heavy object that also happens to not always be safe to touch ... well, anything around it.

So I tossed this together in Tinkercad. Measured the diameter of the torch with calipers, entered that dimension for a cylindrical hole size, combined with a square pyramid, bam - torch base.

This could definitely be improved, but I am happy with what I ended up with, so I'm good for now. Hope someone else finds it useful :)

(The original random name given to this Thing by Tinkercad is included too because it was too glorious)

title: Chinese Bulldog extruder enhaced (a.k.a. triying to make it good)

description.text:
So! i bought this bulldog, thinking: nice! is cheap and it seems to be good! but no.
those friends from china copy this extruder and, the copy it bad. baaaad.
so i use the extruder without spring, for a year now and it works well, but i need some sort of spring inside for compensate the difference in size of the filament, and... it came to this

you will need:
6mm grub screw or blind allen screw.
5mm spring (i use the ones who comes with the bulldog extruder)
all the parts above

the pulley that i use in the extruder is not the one who comes with it, i replace with a 10mm inox one
the two pieces at both sides are the ones who prevent the filament from bending inside the extruder.

recommended material: ABS / ABS-PC

ENJOY

Print the gear with the teeth down. Depending on how well your printer bridges, you may or may not need supports on the gear.

• Cut the tabs off of the motor.
  • Put the gear on the motor
  • Place the hub in its spot. It only fits one way.
  • Place the motor in its spot. Put the wires through the slot in the case.
  • Place the top on the case on top
  • Screw the top case on

description.text:
My daughter requested a microphone for her pop star costume and I decided to design one for her.

I sliced the top grille in Slic3r and printed without any support. As I wanted to do a color change for the shaft and bottom grille, I sliced that part in PrusaControl and to support the lip in the grille connection I printed with support but the the software insisted on support to the bottom of the shaft as well. I designed it so that it should not be needed and other slicers may be able to slice it without the central support column.

To spruce it up a little I also printed a white diffuser and added a color changing led light at the bottom. I have added a 46mm sphere in the package. Take it into your favorite slicer and slice the bottom 9mm of it if you have a similar led light as mine and superglue it to the diffuser.

In addition to the light I knew she would like to add some "gems" so I added 8 x 4mm diameter indents in the grille to accommodate them.

Printer:

Prusa Mk2s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print at 0.15 and 20% infill. Use a brim and supports from build plate on the main mic part.

I did a color change at layer 8.02 and 23.15 for the silver dome. Add other layer changes if you want. I added 2 gold lines at the bottom of the shaft for accent.

The grille is friction fit and pretty tight. Use some light sanding or scraping on the inside lip to make the fit a bit looser.

title: RetroFlag NESPi Embedded NFC Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This are the parts to modify the RetroFlag NESPi case and add a cartridge slot with a functional embedded NFC tray.

The tray included in this project, is a modified version of kiddingme's embedded NFC tray published Apr 9, 2017, his original design can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2238242.

The NFC cartridge in the project is a slim down version of the "Cartridge mod requires no glue" published Jan 31, 2017 by kiddingme, you can find more information about this project at: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073686.

The NFC tag I use for the cartridges are the MIFARE Classic 1K, you can get this from Amazon in packages of 50pcs, this is the link: http://amzn.to/2FfgYru.

Preparation

Before you can use this cartridge slot, your RetroFlag case needs to be modified, follow the instructions on this video by Evan Wright to prepare your case.

Required Hardware

Once you have modified your RetroFalag case you can order an electronic kit to upgrade the functionality of your NESPi console from: https://mini-mods.com/product/retroflag-pi-control-v1.

The NFC reader is use for the Embedded NFC Tray is the: NXP PN532 NFC RFID Module, the link for this product is: https://mini-mods.com/product/nfc-rfid-tag-reader/.

Additionally you will need a Brabantia stile clip for the bottom piece of the case, you can buy this from Amazon.

Installation and Configuration

A full procedure on the installtion and configuration of the Retroflag Pi Control board can be found at: https://mini-mods.com/2018/02/26/setup-retroflag-pi-control-v1-board/ Setup your Retroflag Pi Control v1 Board.

Features
  • Soft-shutdown
  • Custom reset button functionality such as restart game and write game info to NFC tag
  • Fan and temperature control
  • Control LED to display various status details
  • Reverse Polarity Protection

title: Custimizable TUSH bracket (sized for Rubbermaid 21 cup filament storage)

description.text:
I've been working on building a Rubbermaid filament storage system, and I was looking to improve a bit on Jimbo70's system. I printed the TUSH remix but I found that (1) the brackets were too long and (2) they didn't quite fit the spool holders I had printed. I started to tweak my own and then realized that the ability to fine tune with a customizer might be helpful for many.
This lets you control the width of the "valleys" in the bracket as well as the widths of the "peaks" so that you can adjust just right for the results from your printer.
Or you might just want to print the one that I have for your own Rubbermaid filament boxes!

description.text:
Replacement basic foot for desktop ATX tower case.

To get the edges finished smoother so it doesn't snag on flooring or carpet I recommend putting this carefully in an electric drill (small part should fit 1/2" chuck) and file/sand the edges smooth and rounded to get rid of any printer layer imperfections.
This is a 3D printer supplies holder designed to hold a small parts tool box, 2 pliers, 2 screwdrivers, and shear cutters. The use of super glue on the bolts is recommended. 14 bolts required.

This thing is a Y-axis belt-tensioner block for the AM8 modification for the Anet A8 printer.
The AM8 is a design by pheneeny using 2040 Aluminum extrusion for the frame. (Thing# 2263216). The tensioner that this is based on was by Bock_Austria (Thing# 2342054).

Basically this is a beefier block to be used with the tensioner by Bock_Austria. I had issues with deformation under belt tension in the original design, so made this one that is a little more "beefed up".

This enclosure is for the KUMAN 7" LCD: http://www.kumantech.com/kuman-7quot-tft-lcd-capacitive-touch-screen-hdmi-800480-for-raspberry-pi-3-2-model-b-rpi-1-b-a-bb-black-pc-sc7b_p0024.html

This enclosure uses pcb enclosure library - 2 ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781023 ).

While designing this enclosure I discovered that the X and Y axis of my Prusa were not sufficiently close to orthogonality, resulting in a lid that didn't match the enclosure (parallelograms instead of rectangles).
You can use Printer_axis_orthogonality_test.stl to test your printer. Print two copies and stack them, one upside up and one upside down. If the four holes matches, it's ok.

I used M3 x 12 rounded head screws but eventually you can use different screws by customizing files Lid_screw.scad, BoardHole.scad ( included in "pcb enclosure library - 2" library files).

KUMAN_7_LCD_Enclosure_front (.scad, .stl) is the main part of the enclosure.
KUMAN_7_LCD_Enclosure_back (.scad, .stl) is the lid.
KUMAN_7_LCD_Rondelle (.scad, .stl) are some washers with the right thickness to fit M3x12 screws to fix the pcb (if you change screw geometry by modifying BoardHole.scad and everything is ok, this thickness should be automatically recalculated)

Conception.scad is used for design.

KUMAN_7_LCD.scad is the library for this design. It's probably the file you'll include if you want to embed this enclosure in your own design.
I mount I created to hold a roborio and a Jetson with the same footprint to save space

This end-stop mount is based on the AM8 design by pheneeny (Thing# 2263216). I had an issue with the original mount being deformed over time and the z-axis not triggering the endstop correctly.

This "beefed up" version should be able to perform easier without deformation and look a little better.

description.text:
Mounting block for 4 TB6560 stepper motor drivers.

Designed to fit originally in this box

Also is equipped with two 50x50 fans

mounted directly towards the cooling blocks of all 4 driver boards.

You might need to add a drop of silicon glue in between the top of the fans and the cover plate so as to eliminate any vibrations while they are ON.

The motor cables can run from the bottom (If you add 4 spacers while mounting the block on the box you can have enough clearance to do so) and the signal wires can run on the top.

You can remix it to change the mounting spots or you can just mount it as is.
Both ways work just fine.

description.text:
Made a wall mounted spool bracket to use with an 8mm rod.

To get the opposite hand version of the bracket, duplicate the file and mirror the duplicated image in your slicer. I realigned mine as shown in the picture to minimize print time.

The great thing about this bracket is, is that you can print as many as you need for the number of spools or length of rod you may have.

Please check out my spool insert as well. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2653645

print_settings.Notes:: Use concentric external fill pattern and allow single extrusion fill if your slicer supports e.g. Simplyfy3D. If not, just print it and take care for good 1st layer adhesion due to the small surface of the "tube".

title: ZOHD Nano Talon Battery Snap Mount Lithium-Ion 18650 CG Optimizer 4S1P FPV INAV
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hard to install a battery in the nano talon with hitting CG and fully tighten your straps right...? If you're flying a 4S1P 18650 Lithium-Ion pack in your ZOHD Nano Talon thats the solution for mounting and hitting CG exactly every time. These Pieces I printed from TPU (other flexible materials will work as well) are sitting tight on a shrink tube covered 18650 pack and snap into place on the nano talons wood tray. The "back" part slides into the slots from the the top and then back 5mm clamping on the wood tray. The "front" part just sits in the slots from the top. If you're just cruising the Talon its enough to hold your pack. If you have adjusted your CG one time you'll hit it every time again. If your doing acro flying better secure with an additional strap in the front - with a strap just there the access is easy.

As always - Happy Flying! ;)

author: KayCox

description.text:
This is a remix (link below) i haven't modified it yet, but mainly I posted this so I could easily download and print from an STL file. The holes are slightly smaller than a 3/8 bit but otherwise it worked quite well.

This is a drilling jig that is intended to help guide drill holes for adding tungsten weights to the bottom of a pinewood derby car. The default settings are setup for 3/8" diameter weights, and distributing the holes on either side of the shorter of the two axel lengths on the block. You can use the tool to drill 1 or 3 holes in front of the axel and optionally do the same behind if more weight is needed. On my son's car we did 3 in front and 1 behind.
Use the slot to ensure alignment to the axel channel on your block, then clamp it to the body. Add tape to your drill bit once you've determined the depth you need (for the number of weights you are adding, and the depth of the jig).

If you want to flip your car backwards or custom, you can change the axelDistFromRear to the measurement you want.
Based on the heart sculpture by Orbes, but I didn't want the hanger part, so I edited it out with Meshmixer. Not a perfect job, but not to bad for my first try.

I'm using the excellent mod https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2177331 to hold 2x E3Dv6 hotends. The only thing I didn't like from this configuration was part cooling. The stock K8400 part cooling axial fan is rather poor and Bo_Ris duct moved insufficient air, so I have fitted a centrifugal fan to this newly designed duct which attaches to the E3Dv6 mounting block that Bo_Ris designed. I now run my Vertex with 100% fan speed for PLA parts and I can get perfect bow overhangs on benchy!

My centrifugal fan is held in place with some electrical tape for now. When I get some fresh superglue, it'll be glued in place which will look far nicer.

description.text:
This is a little sign into which you can insert a piece of paper that is 110mm (horizontal) x 38mm (vertical) to make a little sign for a display, demo, pricetag or any other use. Feel free to make all you want. A shout out would be nice on here if you make one/some. I'd like to see how it looks in other colors.

I made this to hold Boar's Head product descriptions I cut out of the product nutritional information handout for use during Boar's Head product demo events at Kroger, hence the specific dimensions, but it seems like a good size for a paragraph of text for just about anything.

Different layer height settings really affect the print time. (ie: 0.1 = 4 hours, 0.15 = 2.5 hours)
